note.body:
This is really interesting and exciting, thanks for putting it together. Making the plugin API introspectable has been on my radar for a long time, and we’ve been slowly working towards modernising the API so introspectability is possible. There are a few bits which still need modernising (see #1472) before it’ll be fully possible, but it would be good to start the introspection work now. I hope to finish off #1472 soon.

I’ve left a few quick observations now. The changes look good so far, thanks. The commit messages could include a little more detail of the need for each change (e.g. by linking to https://gi.readthedocs.io/en/latest/annotations/giannotations.html), just to make it easier for people looking back on those commits in future to find further reading.

'Write Review' text box UI doesn’t focus when title label is clicked

note.body:
The `review_row` widget (the “Write a short review”) is a custom widget because there is no libadwaita multi-line entry widget. It’s an `AdwPreferencesRow`, with its markup in `gs-review-dialog.ui`. Presumably the skeleton for that widget was copied from libadwaita’s `AdwEntryRow`, which is what’s used for the “Review Summary”.

Fixing this is probably a case of looking at the differences between the implementation of `AdwEntryRow` and gnome-software’s custom widget, and seeing what focus/activation handling is missing from the latter.

Change name of ‘Software’ to ‘App Center’

note.body:
> soft (digital) ware (market)

It's not a market though. Besides most things being for free, it's also used for removing installed apps, add-ons, OS updates, runtimes, fonts, codecs, language packs, etc. I personally consider those last bits to be data, not software. Technically the term that correctly describes all of those things is "packages" and the term that best describes what it allows you to do with them is "management". That makes sense: it's a graphical front-end for package management.

Of course naming it "Package Manager" isn't gonna fix the issue this thread exists to discuss and every other name suggested doesn't technically cover all the functionality of what the application offers. As dated as they sounds "Center" and "Hub" at least convey a little more meaning than just "Software". "Software" is probably more applicable here than "Apps" but if the purpose is to improve user discoverability, using the term "App" is a more commonly used and understood word these days. That's probably why the two options with "Software" in them were picked the least in the limited polling cited in the first post.

Honestly, the only names that I think would be downgrades are anything that add "Market", "Shop", or "Store". I think that would scare people away.

I’m experiencing similar issues with GNOME Software. When performing updates or downloading an app, the interface becomes completely unresponsive.

Switching tabs (e.g., to Installed or Explore) fails to load content during updates or downloads. This includes switch tabs when doing an update and then going back to the update tab (at which point there is nothing loading to show the progress of the updates). Another example is when updating or downloading something, I am unable to go search other apps in the Explore tab.

This significantly impacts usability, as I can’t browse apps or monitor update progress during these operations. I believe this might align with the blocking behavior described here. Currently I am unable to try going deeper into the cause (as in if it's exactly the same problem as the one described here), but at the start of 2025 I can provide some logs and additional information if needed.

note.body:
> It's true except when parameter invariants aren't respected, which sadly can sometimes happen without realizing, leading to crashes. E.g. you didn't expect a function to be able to return `NULL` and you use its result as the non-nullable argument of a function, leading to dereferencing an unexpectedly `NULL` error pointer, causing a segfault. E.g. https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gnome-software/-/merge_requests/2004#note_2292304.
> 
> Granted that's a programming issue, but it's a sadly somewhat easy mistake to make given the volume of API we work with, and C really doesn't help at all here.

Yeah, I wrote a more detailed reply to this one on the linked thread above, just to try and clear up any confusion.

Indeed, it comes down to the fact that we have to encode parts of the contract of functions using `g_return_val_if_fail()` in C, whereas in a more modern language those contracts (such as nullability of arguments) could be encoded into the API in a way which the compiler could check. It’s one of the unavoidable downsides of C.

> Shouldn't we then stop allocating so many `local_error` objects only to propagate them, and instead directly pass the output `error` argument where possible? Following the rules you linked, it should be true about everywhere.

Sure, passing the `GError **` argument through is neater, but equally I don’t think it’s worth spending loads of time on eliminating use of `local_error` to save some allocations/code. Those allocations only happen in error conditions (i.e. not very often) and are small. And actually when switching from `local_error` to the `GError **` all you save is a `g_steal_pointer()` call, which is just an `if` and a pointer dereference. The error is allocated once by the code which sets it in the first place, and then propagated up by pointer.

target_title: Add plugin gs-plugin-systemd-sysupdate

note.body:
> After some debugging, the issue is that we call `gs_appstream_create_app` with `NULL` as a `component`, which then fails with an assert and doesn't set an error. We then fail to propagate the error, and ultimately end up dereferencing the `NULL` error.

To follow up on this:
 * It’s a precondition of `gs_appstream_create_app()` that a valid non-`NULL` `component` is passed to the function.
 * This is encoded as a `g_return_val_if_fail()` precondition assertion at the top of `gs_appstream_create_app()`.
 * If that precondition assertion fails, that indicates a program bug, and the state of the process is now undefined.
 * It would be incorrect to set a `GError` in that case because `GError`s are for runtime errors, not programming errors. If we set a `GError` for programming bugs, that would dramatically increase the amount of code in the process, and none of that code would be practically testable (so it would itself be full of bugs).
 * The fact that the code ends up dereferencing a `NULL` error after this precondition failure is fine — we’re already into an undefined state, and a critical warning has already been printed highlighting where things went wrong (the precondition). Trying to recover the process back to a well defined and functional state is not worthwhile — save code on that, and put the time you would have spent writing that code into testing the rest of the code. :smile: 
 * These are strong recommendations from GLib about how it’s meant to be used, based on decades of experience of finding the right balance between making programming errors debuggable and having reliable processes.

target_title: Add plugin gs-plugin-systemd-sysupdate

note.body: If a function returns `NULL` with no error set because of a `g_return_val_if_fail()` (which I presume is what you’re referring to?), then we’re into undefined behaviour territory. The calling code doesn’t need to handle that — and in fact shouldn’t, because any code to handle situations like that is untestable.

note.body:
This state update should be moved to where the async function implementation calls `g_task_return_*()`. The `*_finish()` function isn’t guaranteed to be called straight away.

The general rule is that `*_finish()` functions shouldn’t do any work. They are there to marshal the return values out of the `GTask`.

target_title: Add plugin gs-plugin-systemd-sysupdate

note.body:
Does this async operation hold a reference to any of the `app`s in `GsPluginSystemdSysupdateRefineData`? The conventional way to do this would be to hold a ref on each of them in the `GQueue`, but I don’t see that. Am I missing something?

If I’m not missing something (and this needs fixing), then the other async functions which operate on a `GsAppList` should also be checked for refcounting issues like this. I haven’t checked them.

I recommend the fix would be to build a new `GsAppList`, rather than using a `GQueue`. It makes memory management of the elements simpler. Using it should be a straightforward case of swapping out the `g_queue_*()` function calls for `gs_app_list_*()`. Alternatively, you could add `g_object_ref()` to each `g_queue_push_*()` function call, and a paired `g_object_unref()`/`g_autoptr()` to each `g_queue_pop()`.

note.body:
I think that calling `g_steal_pointer()` and `strlen()` on `reply` in the same function call may lead to problems. iirc the order of evaluation of arguments is undefined, so if `strlen()` isn’t called first, it will end up being called as `strlen (NULL)`.

Safer to factor it out as `reply_len = strlen (reply)` earlier.

target_title: Add plugin gs-plugin-systemd-sysupdate

note.body:
I’m nervous about having the `gs_metered_remove_from_download_scheduler()` call in this `*_free()` function because:
 * It makes a D-Bus call
 * That could take an unbounded amount of time
 * We don’t know what context the `*_free()` function will be executed in (will it be part of the main thread? will it be in a separate thread? will it be an idle callback? will it block the main thread?)
 * We don’t know *when* the `*_free()` function will be called — it could end up being called a long time after the download scheduling is needed, meaning the scheduling request is in the scheduler for too long

So I’d recommend that the `gs_metered_remove_from_download_scheduler_async()` call is made explicitly and asynchronously in the relevant places in the main code flow, and the code in this `*_free()` function is changed to `g_assert (data->schedule_entry_handle == NULL)` to check that the schedule entry has been removed.

target_title: gs-common: Fix use of NULL GMainLoop pointer after unmapping dialog

note.body:
> Such behavior is undocumented, thus unsafe to rely on

It’s how async functions have always worked, and have to work: the object which the async call is made on – so the `AdwAlertDialog` in the case of a call to `adw_alert_dialog_choose()` – has to be kept alive until the `_finish` function is called on it. The ‘result’ has always guaranteed this, either through its implementation as a `GTask`, or as a `GSimpleAsyncResult`.

If there’s a demonstrable use-after-free with the code in this MR, please tell me how to trigger it and I’ll investigate.

target_title: gs-common: Fix use of NULL GMainLoop pointer after unmapping dialog

note.body: Such behavior is undocumented, thus unsafe to rely on. Furthermore, if it would ever happen that the function will be called with a window which is not from the libadwaita, a regular dialog is shown (that's documented) and it is freed before the main loop ends (I tested it with passing NULL window argument). Then the use-after-free is "back". I won't bother you with this thread otherwise.

I don’t think this is the right feature for what you want. As Will suggested on Matrix, it won’t work if ibus-cangjie is installed by default, or installed by a different user on the system (such as an administrator). Users may be hesitant to give a donation as soon as they install the software, since they haven’t used it yet.

target_title: eula-dialog: show EULA when specific packages require so

note.body:
I do want to use this feature, but not for a proprietary software EULA: ibus-cangjie can be installed by Software already, it is entirely free software [under the GPLv3+](https://gitlab.freedesktop.org/cangjie/ibus-cangjie/-/blob/main/COPYING?ref_type=heads) and I would love to user this feature to display a question to the users: whether they want to enable a periodic reminder that we could use some donations from them.

IBus Cangjie is not an app with a window, it is an input method to type Chinese with a non-chinese keyboard, and the only place we would show this would be either in the settings window which no one would run, or in a post install page after installation in Software. :confused: 

Please let us ask for optional donations, I'm disabled and don't work anymore, my comaintainer lives in Hong Kong and doesn't earn much money because in Hong Kong nothing pays well. :disappointed:

target_title: Add plugin gs-plugin-systemd-sysupdate

note.body:
This is the point where it crashes

```
#0  0x00007f7207b833f7 in create_app_for_target (self=0x5560e55388d0, target=0x5560e90479b0, error=0x7ffcbf079528) at ../plugins/systemd-sysupdate/gs-plugin-systemd-sysupdate.c:672
672			g_debug ("Couldn't create app for host target, creating fallback: %s", local_error->message);
```

`local_error` is `NULL`. I also noticed another error message on the standard output

```
10:41:58:873 Gs  gs_appstream_create_app: assertion 'XB_IS_NODE (component)' failed
10:41:58:873 GLib g_propagate_error: assertion 'src != NULL' failed
```

After some debugging, the issue is that we call `gs_appstream_create_app` with `NULL` as a `component`, which then fails with an assert and doesn't set an error. We then fail to propagate the error, and ultimately end up dereferencing the `NULL` error.

note.body:
Here you go, a patch to this file bringing it to the current API (what should be released in v257)

```patch
diff --git a/plugins/systemd-sysupdate/org.freedesktop.sysupdate1.xml b/plugins/systemd-sysupdate/org.freedesktop.sysupdate1.xml
index ed972f10..a21bc546 100644
--- a/plugins/systemd-sysupdate/org.freedesktop.sysupdate1.xml
+++ b/plugins/systemd-sysupdate/org.freedesktop.sysupdate1.xml
@@ -95,12 +95,12 @@ SPDX-License-Identifier: GPL-2.0-or-later
    <annotation name="org.freedesktop.DBus.Property.EmitsChangedSignal" value="const"/>
   </property>
   <method name="List">
-   <arg type="b" name="offline" direction="in"/>
+   <arg type="t" name="flags" direction="in"/>
    <arg type="as" name="versions" direction="out"/>
   </method>
   <method name="Describe">
    <arg type="s" name="version" direction="in"/>
-   <arg type="b" name="offline" direction="in"/>
+   <arg type="t" name="flags" direction="in"/>
    <arg type="s" name="json" direction="out"/>
   </method>
   <method name="CheckNew">
@@ -108,12 +108,14 @@ SPDX-License-Identifier: GPL-2.0-or-later
   </method>
   <method name="Update">
    <arg type="s" name="new_version" direction="in"/>
+   <arg type="t" name="flags" direction="in"/>
    <arg type="s" name="new_version" direction="out"/>
    <arg type="t" name="job_id" direction="out"/>
    <arg type="o" name="job_path" direction="out"/>
   </method>
   <method name="Vacuum">
-   <arg type="u" name="count" direction="out"/>
+   <arg type="u" name="instances" direction="out"/>
+   <arg type="u" name="disabled_transfers" direction="out"/>

target_title: Flatpak apps are not displaying properly in search results or app detail screens in gnome-software.

note.body:
Thanks for a bug report. I see near the top of the log plenty of `cannot process content type application/octet-stream` errors when reading appstream data. The gnome-software depends on these, that's where it takes the information about the available apps. These errors mention `ca.archive.ubuntu.com_ubuntu_dists_oracular` int he file name, thus something related to the packaged stuff, not the Flatpak stuff.

The log shows that some Flatpak apps had been updated. There are also some missing icons.

When I search for the `clairv` here, it shows the Flathub app with no problem. It is not installed here. The system Flatpak saves the required Appstream data under the `/var/lib/flatpak/appstream/` in Fedora, for the `flathub` remote it's `flathub/x86_64/active/` subdirectory. It should contain `appstream.xml` and some other files. The `cat /var/lib/flatpak/appstream/flathub/x86_64/active/appstream.xml | grep com.github.cassidyjames.clairvoyant` returns several hits here, one `<id>...</id>`.

target_title: gs-common: Fix use of NULL GMainLoop pointer after unmapping dialog

note.body:
> The `unmap` signal is emitted after `g_main_loop_run()` has returned and the reference to the `GMainLoop` dropped.

Being it ^^^ true, then this:

> This results in `shutdown_loop()` being called with a `NULL` `GMainLoop` pointer.

is sort of (sometimes) false, because the first means the stack-allocated `RunInfo` might be deallocated, thus the `shutdown_loop()` is called on an already freed memory, which can point to anything. If quick enough, it can be the nullified `run_info.loop` or something else.

I suggest to not depend on the `unmap`, but use only the `AdwDialog::closed` signal instead and call the `shutdown_loop()` only in the `closed` handler. Bonus points if the `unmap_cb` replacement does not take the `RunInfo`, but a referenced `GMainLoop` instead, to avoid accessing stack-allocated memory, which may or may not be gone. As long as the dialog is freed on close, the handler's data can be freed (the loop unreffed) as well.

> * Is the app the right one

- This is primarily for installing well known apps (wrt the user) and removing already installed apps, where loading the details page is unnecessary.

- Also, there is no guarantee that the user will do all these checks even if on details page before every `Install`. It's an assumption that the user will scroll down and do all checks, if I'm not wrong.

> Which source should I install it from

The idea was to display a small dialog showing possible origins to `Install` / `Remove` from. IIUC, this dialog needs to be implemented at some point, while clicking `Uninstall..` from the `Installed` page.

target_title: gs-update-monitor: Watch for changes to GSettings check-timestamp

note.body:
> Only looking into the `check_updates`, it runs several jobs before it changes the `check-timestamp`, and even with that changed there is a `check_language_pack()` called early in the `check_updates()`, unconditionally,.

This is how the update monitor works though: it calls `check_updates()` whenever it’s possible that updates need to be checked for (see, for example, `check_hourly_cb()` or the other signal callbacks).

Yes, it’s an issue that `check_updates()` calls `check_language_pack()`, and I think that needs to be reworked, but it’s a separate issue from this one — it would still need to be reworked even if this MR didn’t land. I plan to rework it as part of the threading work (language packs are the next item on the list for that).

target_title: Add quick actions (install/remove) to app tiles

note.body:
What’s the use case?

I don’t think this will be a useful addition. The user needs to make decisions when installing an app, and this won’t let them do that. In particular:
 - Is the app the right one
 - How much space will it take up
 - How secure is it
 - What will it do with my data
 - Which source should I install it from

target_title: gs-update-monitor: Watch for changes to GSettings check-timestamp

note.body:
It's kinda hard to do a real review at the moment (GNOME GitLab instability), thus just a note: This runs the handler for any change in the settings, not only in the related properties. Count to it that the GSettings is documented as unreliable, as it does not notify when anything changed, but when "something could change" + having the callback called for each probable key change means a flood of "maybe you may run update check". Only looking into the `check_updates`, it runs several jobs before it changes the `check-timestamp`, and even with that changed there is a `check_language_pack()` called early in the `check_updates()`, unconditionally,.

Considering you want it for the developers, not for the end users, even though the code will be executed for unrelated possible changes in the GSettings for everybody, I'm wondering whether such performance hit does worth it. Compare with:
```
gnome-software --quit
for key in `gsettings list-keys org.gnome.software | grep timestamp`; do gsettings reset org.gnome.software $key; done
gnome-software--verbose
```
which has no impact on the users, neither developers.

target_title: Not showing system updates on fedora

note.body:
If the PackageKit API allowed gnome-software to skip the `pk_client_get_updates_async()` call for just the one repo which is failing, I think that would be fine. But as it is, if this operation isn’t fatal then one broken repo will remove all update severity information for all PackageKit packages. So `GS_PLUGIN_REFINE_FLAGS_REQUIRE_UPDATE_SEVERITY` would be effectively useless.

The fix here is for PackageKit to be fixed.

It’s been a while since I looked at that code, but if the tests are using a `dbus-daemon` subprocess with a controlled environment using `g_test_dbus_*()`, it will *always* handle `org.freedesktop.DBus` calls (as it is `org.freedesktop.DBus`). The way to get your service listed in `ListActivatableNames` is to create a mock `.service` file directory with a `.service` file for the mock `sysupdate1` service, using `g_test_dbus_add_service_dir()`.

target_title: Not showing system updates on fedora

note.body:
Looks to be caused by this dnf repo failure:
```
23:39:36:310 Gs  plugin 'packagekit' failed to refine apps: failed to get updates for urgency: cannot update repo 'insync': Cannot download repomd.xml: Cannot download repodata/repomd.xml: All mirrors were tried; Last error: Status code: 404 for http://yum.insync.io/fedora/41/repodata/repomd.xml (IP: 2400:52e0:1e00::864:1)
```

The `cannot update repo` message comes from [`dnf_repo_update()` in `dnf-repo.cpp`](https://github.com/rpm-software-management/libdnf/blob/dnf-4-master/libdnf/dnf-repo.cpp#L1903), where it returns a `DNF_ERROR_CANNOT_FETCH_SOURCE`.

PackageKit’s dnf backend [checks for this error code](https://github.com/PackageKit/PackageKit/blob/main/backends/dnf/pk-backend-dnf-refresh.c#L99) and should skip the repo if it fails, so I’m not sure what’s happening there.

What happens if you try `pkcon update`?

note.body:
I do not know since when I had prepared the below comment. It's hard to say since the unreliable GitLab instance here for the past days/weeks. It's somewhat relevant, thus I'm sending it now.

It's complicated. There are "online" and "offline" updates. Those "offline" are package updates, which for example PackageKit plugin prepares for update and applies on reboot, when the machine is offline. In contrast, the Flatpak plugin can apply updates immediately, aka "online". The rpm-ostree should behave similarly as the PackageKit plugin, just download and prepare the update for the next reboot. The "apply" here does not mean to make it use immediately, but to stage it for the next reboot. The fwupd plugin can do both types, if I recall correctly.

target_title: Better handling of missing screenshot case

note.body:
Yes, I repeated it on many places. There are users whom do not want to have spammed their journal with things they cannot do anything with. That makes perfect sense, at least to me.

I, as a developer, am fine with these warnings, but it's me as a developer, not as a regular user. The `g_return_if_fail()` and similar things are showing problems in the app, thus they are good to be reported. The things which are out of the user control, and even out of the app control, like the server temporarily offline or broken or whatever, is something you might want to see, but apart of "ah, this is why" they are useless.

You are right, the verbose log is really verbose, it's hard to find the right thing in it, but it's also a way to figure out why something does not work, with a broader context.

target_title: Resolve "App icons are blurred until the app is installed with 200% scaling"

note.body:
What are the users supposed to do with it? If nothing, or better if they cannot do anything with it, then it should be `g_debug()`. No need to bother them.

This also catches on the cache, I've cached icons in it from the "before patched gnome-software" and the icons in the cache do not match expectations. Bothering user's journal with that does not help.

One example, but I see many of those:
```
12:36:16:077 Gs  Icon downloaded from ‘https://dl.flathub.org/media/app/devsuite/Ptyxis/9848d809e4512f4075298235b620e541/icons/128x128@2/app.devsuite.Ptyxis.png’ has dimensions 80x80@2, but was expected to have dimensions 128x128@2 according to metadata. Overriding with downloaded dimensions.
```

The `g_warning()` does not know whether the icon had been taken from the cache or from the server... Maybe, this is the chance to download it. When the cached image does not match the expectation, then download the icon again, instead of the `g_warning()`. Some "what if the server side is really faulty" check, to not download the same icon repeatedly only because of the server's fault, would be good to have.

target_title: Better handling of missing screenshot case

note.body:
> if the user cannot do anything about it, then do not spam their journal with it

I think you've mentioned this same point in multiple places in the past, but I honestly don't understand this. I think it's exactly for cases like this, where a warning in the console would be useful. If we go by your point, almost nothing should be displayed in the console or journal, as users can't do much with anything that goes to the journal. In the same way, `g_warning` should never exist, only `g_debug`.

I think `g_debug` / `--verbose` is for debugging non-trivial issues. They produce tons of information and it's a lot of effort from requesting the logs to user, viewing / analyzing the logs and arriving at a conclusion. A simple warning in console can get this information in seconds.

Warnings are something which a normal user should be able to say in Discourse thread / GitLab issue.

E.g. `I can see the following 'Warning: foo bar failed' message in the console. Is this cause of this issue ?` etc.

target_title: Better handling of missing screenshot case

note.body: Sounds good to me, I've only a comment for the "display a warning in console" part: if the user cannot do anything about it, then do not spam their journal with it. There's the `--verbose` log for this. I may mention that I find useful to see these warnings without the `--verbose` logging on, but I'm a developer, not a regular user, which is a huge difference.

note.body:
Both problems seem to be caused by `dnf` not being happy about the signing key for one of your repos. It should also have been warning you about this when using it from the command line.

Here’s the relevant part of the log for installing the RPM file:
```
09:32:19:823 Gs  running FileToApp job with dedupe-flags=7, elapsed time since creation 25052ms
09:32:19:823 Gs  running UrlToApp job with dedupe-flags=7, elapsed time since creation 26493ms
09:32:19:823 Gs  failed to convert URL to GsApp: Failed to file-to-app from file: URL:Failed to resolve package_ids: ca
nnot update repo 'pgdg-common': repomd.xml GPG signature verification error: Signing key not found
```

Here’s the relevant part of the logs for updating:
```
09:30:01:652 Gs  plugin 'packagekit' failed to refine apps: failed to get updates for urgency: cannot update repo 'pgdg-common': repomd.xml GPG signature verification error: Signing key not found
```

You’ll need to either disable the `pgdg-common` repo from the repositories window in gnome-software, or update its key using the instructions on https://yum.postgresql.org/news/pgdg-rpm-repo-gpg-key-update/.

note.body:
OK, let’s land this. Sorry for the delay, and thank you everyone for your persuasive input. It seems we might get a more specific approach for it from GTK in the long term, but not in the immediate future (https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gtk/-/issues/6680), so let’s fix it in gnome-software for now.

I’ve pushed a tweaked version of this MR which keeps the properties and changes them to focusable=true with a comment, to prevent the focus accidentally being removed again in future (because unless you’re using accessibility technologies, it does look like a bug that these rows are focusable).

With GTK 4.16, the dialog doesn’t actually open with a blue outline on the first row (with this MR applied) unless you’ve been using keyboard navigation in the last few seconds, so that lessens the impact of this for many non-accessibility-technology users.

note.body:
IIRC you should run the following (in the cloned repo on the correct branch ofc) 

```
$ meson --prefix $PWD/install -Dpackagekit=false -Drpm_ostree=true build/
$ ninja -C build/ all install
$ killall gnome-software
$ XDG_DATA_DIRS=install/share:$XDG_DATA_DIRS LD_LIBRARY_PATH=install/lib64/:$LD_LIBRARY_PATH ./install/bin/gnome-software
```
(To install the dependencies, rather than layering them, I created a toolbox and installed them by running the `dnf` and `pip3` commands in [the CI dockerfile](https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gnome-software/-/blob/main/.gitlab-ci/fedora.Dockerfile). The last command may need to be run on the host system instead of the toolbox.)

~~My problem when testing is I don't know of any reliable way of triggering the auto update. I had found a semi reliable way by essentially running `killall gnome-software` asap after boot before running my build but even then...  
Maybe the maintainers know of a better way to trigger the auto update, but I couldn't find any.~~  
Check next comment for instructions to trigger auto update.

I also used journalctl to keep an eye on what the ostree daemon was doing. I believe the command was `journalctl -f -u rpm-ostreed`.

note.body:
Right. In which case, `0.63.0` should match the `meson_version` in GS, which it does not.

```meson
project('gnome-software', 'c',
  version : '48.alpha',
  license : 'GPL-2.0-or-later',
  default_options : ['warning_level=2', 'c_std=c11'],
  meson_version : '>=0.58.0'
)
```

So, I assume its the maximum of the minimum required `meson_version` of GS and all its subprojects, which matches `0.63.0`.

```
./meson.build:5:  meson_version : '>=0.58.0'
./subprojects/libxmlb/meson.build:4:  meson_version : '>=0.60.0',
./subprojects/libadwaita/meson.build:4:    meson_version: '>= 0.59.0',
./subprojects/gtk/examples/hello/meson.build:3:          meson_version: '>= 0.50.0',
./subprojects/gtk/meson.build:10:        meson_version : '>= 0.63.0',
```

Now that we're not build GTK / libadwaita from source, we should revisit this.

```

Draft: rpm-ostree: Stage updates when automatic updates are on

note.body:
Perhaps an approach which is more specific to rpm-ostree would be to change `GS_APP_STATE_UPDATABLE` to `GS_APP_STATE_UPDATABLE_LIVE` only within `gs-plugin-rpm-ostree.c`, and drop this change from `gs-update-monitor.c`.

aiui rpm-ostree updates do qualify as ‘live’ updates (just like flatpaks) as the update operation is done while the machine is running in a normal session. Only the deploy is done when restarting. In contrast, non-live (or ‘offline’) updates are done while the machine is in a special low-level boot state.

The _downloads_ for both types of update are done in advance.

note.body: Assertion failures are treated as crashes, because they indicate that some program logic is badly wrong. The program may well crash due to whatever underlying bug causes the assertion failure.

target_title: Better handling of missing screenshot case

note.body:
I think we can do the following:

1. When a screenshot download fails, we should retry N (say N=3) times for retryable errors (not 404 etc). This is mainly to account for https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/glib/-/issues/3079 etc.
2. If at least 1 screenshot can be shown, display the screenshot in the the UI. For failed screenshots, do not report errors in UI, but display a warning in console.
3. If all screenshot download failed or are missing, then display a `No Screenshots` placeholder image as shown in [above comment](https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gnome-software/-/issues/2261#note_1808492). For failed screenshots, do not report errors in UI, but display a warning in console.
4. Not showing the `No Screenshots` placeholder image for some apps will be confusing. The placeholder image will also make users report it as an issue to upstream app.

note.body:
Just FYI.

For simulating network delay / UI hang, I used the following `tc` commands (as sudo / root). This adds delay to the network traffic on a particular NIC.

### Add delay:

```
# tc qdisc add dev <iface_name> root netem delay 100000ms
```

### Remove delay:

```
# tc qdisc del dev <iface_name> root
```

where `<iface_name>` is network interface name (`eth0` / `lo` etc.).

note.body: I’ve pushed a couple of additional commits which I think tidy up a few loose ends here. Review welcome. I haven’t touched any of your previous commits.

target_title: Resolve "App icons are blurred until the app is installed with 200% scaling"

note.body:
We do actually know the scale the icon was downloaded at, because it comes from the app’s metainfo (and that contains width, height and scale). There are only a couple of places in the code base where we create a `GsRemoteIcon` without knowing the scale information out-of-band and those are all `flatpakref`, `flatpakrepo` and snap files (see the final commit in the MR).

So one of my other two commits on this MR reworks this line of code slightly so that the scale is not overwritten here, and is instead left as what was set by the metainfo code. `gs_icon_get_scale()` guarantees to return something ≥1 (even as a default), so we don’t need to set the scale to 1 if we don’t know a better value — the default is 1.

push_data.commit_title: plugins: Document why GsRemoteIcon dimensions aren’t set

note.body:
> `Nov 15 00:31:07 x1-carbon-clement fwupd[2214]: 23:31:07.733 Fwupd                (null) is not a valid device ID`

That looks like an interesting line. gnome-software doesn’t directly call any of the functions which emit that critical warning (`fu_device_set_equivalent_id()`, `fwupd_device_set_id()`, `fwupd_device_set_parent_id()`, `fwupd_device_set_composite_id()`), although it may call them transiently. The warning may equally well be triggered from inside the fwupd daemon.

@hughsie have you seen this recently/before?

This could be debugged further by temporarily changing the environment for `fwupd.service` so that it will coredump when this critical warning is emitted. The coredump can then be uploaded here.

```sh
sudo systemctl edit --runtime fwupd.service
# add the following (without the comment markers):
# [Service]
# Environment="G_DEBUG=fatal-criticals"
sudo systemctl restart fwupd.service
# trigger the firmware update (probably by pressing refresh in the updates view in gnome-software, then trying to download it)
# wait for fwupd.service to crash (this will be visible in the system journal)
coredumpctl list  # find the crash data for fwupd.service
coredumpctl info $coredump_id
coredumpctl dump $coredump_id --output ./dump-file
```

and attach the log messages, dump info and core file here please.

target_title: Display `Removals` at start of System Updates dialog

note.body:
By design, gnome-software should not be doing unintended package removals. It doesn’t set any options with behaviour like `--allow-remove-essential`. If essential packages get removed as part of an update, then that’s a packaging bug.

We can’t expect users to look at the list of changed packages and work out what makes sense and what doesn’t. The list has to make sense and be safe. 99% of our target audience don’t even know what a package is, let alone whether removing `libxkbregistry0-dbgsym` is safe.

target_title: Display `Removals` at start of System Updates dialog

note.body:
> You could equally well phrase it the other way round (“every time I update my system I have to scroll down past the removals to see package additions”) — I don’t think either approach is necessarily higher priority than the other.

Unintended package removals during update can break the system. On the contrary, it's normal for new packages to be installed as part of system update. So, `Removals` section is important than `Additions` when it comes to System Update.

Below are some options in `man apt-get` which explain this.

### 1. Acceptable to install new packages as part of update:

```
       --with-new-pkgs
           Allow installing new packages when used in conjunction with upgrade. This is useful if the update of an
           installed package requires new dependencies to be installed. Instead of holding the package back upgrade
           will upgrade the package and install the new dependencies. Note that upgrade with this option will never
           remove packages, only allow adding new ones. Configuration Item: APT::Get::Upgrade-Allow-New.
```

### 2. Not acceptable to remove existing packages as part of update:

```
       --allow-remove-essential
           Force yes; this is a dangerous option that will cause apt to continue without prompting if it is removing
           essentials. It should not be used except in very special situations. Using it can potentially destroy
           your system! Configuration Item: APT::Get::allow-remove-essential. Introduced in APT 1.1.
```

```
       --no-remove
           If any packages are to be removed apt-get immediately aborts without prompting. Configuration Item:
           APT::Get::Remove.
```

target_title: Display `Removals` at start of System Updates dialog

note.body:
This needs brief input from a designer, but I don’t think it’s worth spending much time on. You could equally well phrase it the other way round (“every time I update my system I have to scroll down past the removals to see package additions”) — I don’t think either approach is necessarily higher priority than the other.

Designers, can you easily think of a way that both package additions and removals could be made visible/pertinent without scrolling? If it takes more than 2 mins to do so, I think this issue should just be closed — I don’t think it’s important enough to spend time on when everything else is so on fire.

target_title: hardware-support: Fix erroneous compatibility warnings
Misrepresented hardware support

note.body:
It seems like many of the problems described above are caused by a single issue: if any of the five categories (desktop, mobile, keyboard, mouse and touch) are not fulfilled, the overall rating is downgraded to "will not work properly". So no matter what the actual screen size is, if the application is not compatible with both mobile and desktop, it won't be shown as compatible. Similarly, if the application doesn't support all the available input methods it is marked incompatible.

I think the correct approach would be to only base the compatibility rating on whether the current display size is supported, and if at least one of the supported input methods is available.

target_title: Add plugin gs-plugin-systemd-sysupdate

note.body:
I think it makes a lot of sense to be strict about metadata, for everything except for the `host` target. Updating the `host` target is how a distribution would release a bugfix in case they mess up the appstream metainfo. So for the `host` target, and that target only, I'd have a basic fallback that reads os-release and populates a GsApp with information from there.

Also, gnome-software should probably log warnings about any targets it encounters that lack appstream metadata.

Just make sure you don't cache os-release information for the fallback. There's no need to cache  this information: it's only used once to create a single GsApp, and then that GsApp gets cached.

note.body: I don’t think this is worth tracking in an issue. I don’t see how this could affect user behaviour. If you want the string to be pedantically correct, you could submit a merge request to change it to “x%d downloaded and verified”, but adding a lot more app states or the capacity to pass a custom progress string from the plugin to the UI (as Milan correctly says is what would be necessary to change this) is too much churn to change something like this.

target_title: OS upgrade progress message string is inaccurate
Not enough disk space errors should provide more context

note.body:
Yes, they should provide more context, but that needs to be balanced against making the error message unnecessarily technical.

I suggest we should aim for something like:
 * Always display how much space was needed vs how much was available. This might need additional API from PackageKit to expose that information in a machine readable way.
 * If there’s only one main partition, don’t mention anything about partitions.
 * If there’s more than one main partition, give the path of the root of the partition containing `/var/cache/PackageKit/41/metadata` (or whichever path PackageKit says is the problem; this may require additional PackageKit API). We may be able to give an less technical string using `g_unix_mount_guess_name()`, if what that function returns matches up with what’s shown in the disk usage analyser when the user presses ‘Examine Disk’.

That sounds fine by me. Even if there is some hint (via `AdwToast` etc) in the UI, I'd make sure to update my system first. Main issue here is doing upgrade without update might look lucrative (as it's faster) to some uninformed users and that upgrade path is a hit and miss as pointed above.

target_title: search entry has inconsistent padding
Require/recommend all other updates to be installed before allowing to start system upgrade

note.body: There were some discussions on how to identify "important" vs "non-important" updates before doing the upgrade. But it's all error-prone. E.g. there can be some scriptlet error in _any_ package that triggers an error only during a version upgrade. There would need to be a whole infrastructure about how to mark those important updates. So in DNF we simply recommend to fully update the system first, that's the safest route.

target_title: Require/recommend all other updates to be installed before allowing to start system upgrade

note.body:
Being it only about UI, it's easy (@aday could you make a mockup or suggestion, please?), but doing it always, when the user clicks on the "Restart & Upgrade", would be worse, because it requires two reboots and the update can invalidate the downloaded bits for the upgrade. From that, I'd say, when the "Download" for the system upgrade is clicked, it may check whether any updates are pending [1] and ask to update first in some fancy way, if there are, still leaving the decision to the user.

[1] there are multiple different kinds of the update and most of them are not needed (firmware, flatpak, snap,....). Might it be "section for 'requires restart' contains any items to update" check or some such, I guess.

target_title: gs_details_page_write_review: assertion failed: (self->review_dialog == NULL)

note.body:
It's easier to reproduce when closing the review dialog by a press of the Space key, at least here. I just click on the Review Button, thus it has focus, and then press and release the Space to open & close the dialog. I can even hold down the Space to open&close the dialog in a quick cadence.

I added some debug prints and simply the dialog is fully destroyed after the "write review" button is pressed, which (not proved) could be due to the button gets focused before the key-press event is finished and the key-release signal is received by the "write review" button and it creates the dialog again. Or I'd guess something like that happened, related to the focus switch and delivery of the signals. That it doesn't happen always adds to the fun of this bug.

As the dialog is properly destroyed, I would remove the assert and in the `review_dialog_destroy_cb` check whether the `self->review_dialog` is truly the destroyed dialog and NULL-ify it only if it is. Or similar check for a `g_object_weak_ref` callback, if one would like to avoid the "destroy" signal usage.

target_title: Distro upgrade fails from FC40 -> FC41 with latest GNOME Software

note.body:
Thanks for a bug report. From the log, in each group (as you separated it), the third is caused by the second, which is caused by the first, thus the first is the problem here.

In the PackageKit 1.2.8 the `pk_task_upgrade_system_async` creates a `GSimpleAsyncResult` as an async operation result object, while the `pk_client_generic_finish` checks the passed in `GAsyncResult` is a `GTask`.

Looking around, there is a `pk_task_generic_finish()` too, which means the gnome-software uses incorrect "generic_finish" function in this (or more) place(s). In other words, jobs started with `pk_task...` should be finished with `pk_task_generic_finish()` and jobs started with `pk_client_...()` should be finished with `pk_client_generic_finish()`. They do basically the same thing, only checking for a different type of the `res` in the PackageKit 1.2.8, while they used to use the same type in some earlier versions and they are the same in the 1.3.0 for sure (both parts ported to the `GTask` API from the `GSimpleAsyncResult` API), thus it was not spotted earlier.

Feel free to open a merge request, if you want to.

target_title: Distro upgrade fails from FC40 -> FC41 with latest GNOME Software

note.body:
I didn't look into the exact issue (as it appears to be an issue with PK task ref etc), but:

* GS in FC40 works with `PackageKit` in FC40.
* GS in git doesn't work with `PackageKit` in FC40.
* GS in git works with newer `PackageKit`. (e.g. 1.3.0)

But, we still have `'>= 1.2.5'` in meson.build as below.

```meson
if get_option('packagekit')
  packagekit = dependency('packagekit-glib2', version : '>= 1.2.5')
  conf.set('HAVE_PACKAGEKIT', '1')
...
...
endif
```

I'm not sure if this was already discussed elsewhere, but I think we should enforce some versioning here.

target_title: Flatpak / snap operations should not block PackageKit operations

note.body:
If I'm not mistaken, the "any app can be refined by this plugin" is checked inside the worker thread of the flatpak plugin and this worker thread can do only a single task at the moment, thus anything running in this thread blocks everything else.

An option for the async calls would be to check "does this make any sense for my plugin" in the async itself and do an early finish before passing the processing to the worker thread. It's an extra code for each async job implementation, and it may not always work (when refining a wildcard), but it can cover some common cases like that yours.

This is only a brain storming from my side though.

target_title: Flatpak / snap operations should not block PackageKit operations

note.body:
It is not related to the threading rework, it was like this all the time. Every job is executed on all plugins and finishes only after all the plugins are finished with it. A slow plugin can "block" the job.

When the plugin can run only a single task at the moment, then it causes another level of the job piling.

Somewhat related bug: https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gnome-software/-/issues/1748

target_title: Automatic Update Frequency is Fixed to "Every 14 days"

note.body:
As an end-user, relatively new to Linux distributions, daily driving Gnome for few years, I could drop my two cents:

I somewhat understand that if you go to "Updates" tab and see downloadable updates even if you have automatic updates enabled. There can be the case that new updates were downloaded 1 hour ago, but something new is now available that the automatic process did not yet catch.

But it probably comes down to the question how technically correct the button text needs to be. Showing "Download" when you have automatic update downloads enabled is both confusing and not confusing depending on how the user thinks about it.

Personally, I think showing only the "Apply" button is less confusing, regardless how the user thinks about it. Probably less technically correct, but I don't think everything needs to be technically correct. Maybe updates that are already downloaded or needs to be downloaded could be differentiated in the list with some sort of tag if it needs to be communicated to the user.

As a side note, I always thought the automatic update downloads do not work correctly until I found this open issue. Personally, I download and install updates daily so the current automatic updates work for me twice a month. I think the customizable check+download frequency is definitely also needed.

target_title: Automatic Update Frequency is Fixed to "Every 14 days"

note.body:
I find it confusing that I've selected to have updates be "Automatic" yet when I open Software to install a package or another, I see the "Updates" tab with multiple updates, and when I go there I see I can "Download" them immediately. This makes me question "But I thought these were automatic?". I can the press that button and have them Download/Install right then and there, and get that button to install and reboot if necessary, but isn't this just what "Manual" is and was supposed to be? 

I feel it'd make much more sense if I either never saw "Updates" to have new items if I'm using the "Automatic" or any time I'd see such updates, it'd just be the button to apply & restart.

Blindly trusting that anything automatic is actually happening to updates when I have no indication of that, and I have some indication of the opposite seems like a big ask for anyone who isn't diving into the docs to "figure it out" 🤔

target_title: Updating snap shows authentication dialog

note.body:
From Jamesh comments, I think it's the later.

His point was, that a lot of closely related snap actions are bundled within a single all-in-one snap API, and that API is protected by PolKit auth. If future, when the all-in-one API is split into different smaller APIs, then the `refresh` API can be made to not require PolKit auth by updating [polkit/io.snapcraft.snapd.policy](https://github.com/canonical/snapd/blob/master/data/polkit/io.snapcraft.snapd.policy).

It's still unsure how this happens.

If you've still the old machine, and the gnome-software claims the same error, could you run the following command from a terminal, please?

```
   pkcon upgrade-system 41
```

It will either exhibit the same problem, print the same error, or it'll correct the PackageKit local cache, after which the gnome-software will work again, though I hope for the same error message. Even if it'll go down to the "Ready to restart and install" state, try to close gnome-software and then run from a terminal:

```
   gnome-software --quit
   gnome-software
```

which will restart it. Then, in the Updates tab, the things may have the same result as with the `pkcon` command.

target_title: Version history out of order

note.body:
IIRC gnome-software sorts on the `version` attribute, which is the right thing to do, as apps may release point releases for an older stable branch after they release newer development (or new-stable) branches, so the timestamps aren’t in the same order that apply to updates.

The problem here is with the metainfo for GNOME Boxes: it needs to use `version="47~beta"` so that sorts before `version="47.0"`. This is [documented in the appstream spec](https://www.freedesktop.org/software/appstream/docs/chap-AppStream-Misc.html#spec-vercmp-recommendations) and in the [GNOME release checklist](https://handbook.gnome.org/maintainers/making-a-release.html#for-the-git-commit).

Philip, Milan: Should we have a `Yesterday` instead of `1 day ago` ?

```diff
--- a/src/gs-common.c
+++ b/src/gs-common.c
@@ -940,6 +940,8 @@ gs_utils_time_to_string (gint64 unix_time_seconds)
                return g_strdup_printf (ngettext ("%d hour ago",
                                                  "%d hours ago", hours_ago),
                                        hours_ago);
+       else if (days_ago < 2)
+               return g_strdup_printf (_("Yesterday"));
        else if (days_ago < 15)
                return g_strdup_printf (ngettext ("%d day ago",
                                                  "%d days ago", days_ago),
```

target_title: Add plugin gs-plugin-systemd-sysupdate

note.body:
Yeah, I normally use prototypes and keep the functions written in the same order they’ll be executed for async stuff, as Adrien has. If you skip over the function boilerplate, I find it makes the logic flow easier to read. It also means the async boilerplate is easier to verify, for example whether the `user_data` argument to a function is transfer-full in the caller; how it’s handled in the callback is only a few lines further down the file.

Please keep it as-is Adrien :)

target_title: Flatapks are auto-updated when on a metered connection

note.body:
Do you mean the update happened while you've been connected to both networks, one being metered (with the Internet access) and one not (without the Internet access), and when gnome-software asked whether the network connection is metered, then the GNetworkMonitor found one connection is not metered, thus the update continued and when the other part of the update process wanted to get the files to be downloaded it picked the metered connection, because it has the Internet access and downloaded the files from there?

From the `GNetworkMonitor`'s `network-metered` property documentation:

```
Whether the network is considered metered.

That is, whether the system has traffic flowing through
the default connection that is subject to limitations set
by service providers. ...
```

I doubt the gnome-software itself can pick which route (device) will be used to download the bits, more because it's done in a library (flatpak) the gnome-software uses, which uses another library for the connections (libcurl or libsoup).

I can imagine a counter example, someone having both connections as you (one metered and one not, but both with the Internet access) and would like to update through the home network.

If the `GNetworkMonitor` documentation is correct, then I guess setting the metered connection as the default connection should help in your case. How to set the connection to be the default, as considered by the `GNetworkMonitor` I do not know, I'm sorry.

note.body:
> how can you close it before the problem is solved?

Because, as I have explained, I don’t think this is a separate problem from #2703. I might be wrong, but on the balance of probability, based on my experience of developing and maintaining these components, I think they are the same problem. If you provide data which proves they are separate problems, then we can open well-defined separate issues to track fixing them. Before then, tracking them separately is pointless, and adds noise to the issue list. The issue list is something which I use as a daily work tool, and it’s well within my rights as a maintainer to want to keep that clean and easy to read. Having issues open in it which are not actionable, and do not demonstrate a well-defined bug, makes it harder for me to use.

To put it another way: this is not a customer support ticket tracker, it’s a bug tracker. Maintainers keep issues open because they accurately and specifically describe a confirmed bug to be fixed. We don’t keep issues open just because the reporter is dissatisfied.

> After running these commands, days passed and I could not reproduce the problem. The problem was temporarily solved.

Based on those commands, it definitely looks like there was an issue with your Tracker state. That’s separate from gnome-software. If you can reproduce the problem with Tracker, please re-open https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/localsearch/-/issues/371 and answer Sam’s questions there, as that’s likely where that bug lies.

Do not re-open that issue if you can no longer reproduce the problem, as Sam will have no information on which to base a fix. i.e. The issue will be unactionable and it will stay open forever.

target_title: tracker-extract-3 excessive CPU capacity consumption issue, with gnome-software open

note.body:
After running these commands, days passed and I could not reproduce the problem. The problem was temporarily solved.

`tracker3 reset --filesystem`

`tracker3 daemon -t`

`cd ~/.config/autostart`

`cp -v /etc/xdg/autostart/tracker-*.desktop ./`

`for FILE in tracker-*.desktop; do echo Hidden=true >> $FILE; done`

`rm -rf ~/.cache/tracker ~/.local/share/tracker`

`systemctl --user mask tracker-miner-fs-3`

`systemctl --user status tracker-miner-fs-3.service`

`journalctl --user -u tracker-miner-fs-3.service`

`grep -r -e tracker /etc/xdg/autostart`

The source of the problem was not resolved. Other users who did not do these steps may also experience this problem. Therefore, it is necessary to find out the source of the problem and fix whatever is causing the problem. So leave the topic open. I will try to reproduce the problem.

target_title: Draft: shell: Port to AdwNavigationView

note.body:
> I don't understand what's happening in that video.

I don't really know either, which is why I asked. I'll try to explain as best as I can.

If I open a category page (e.g. "Create"), open any app inside, and finally press Ctrl+F, GNOME Software will go back to the search page - intended, as per status quo. Once I toggle off search, I'll be brought to the page I was previously on - intended as well.

However, if I press back (either via Esc or the back button), it'll immediately jump back to the search page with the search bar revealed. If I toggle off again, I'll be brought to the category page I was on. When I go back again, it reopens the search page. And finally, once I toggle off search, it brings me to the overview.

What it _should_ be doing instead is, after toggling off search the first time, it should go back to the category page I was on, and then back to the overview, without reopening the search page.

note.body: What do you mean "default Adwaita theme"? This is a libadwaita application and should always use `Adwaita-empty`

target_title: Freeze when viewing a certain app's detail (Denaro)

note.body: Is this issue seen with the default Adwaita theme ?

target_title: search entry has inconsistent padding

note.body: it doesn't really annoy me but it's noticeable and i saw it reported and fixed in another project (https://gitlab.gnome.org/World/fractal/-/issues/1499) so i reported here too

target_title: search entry has inconsistent padding
Draft: shell: Port to AdwNavigationView

note.body: @pwithnall is https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gnome-software/-/merge_requests/2132/diffs?commit_id=b1408faacc7b727ef6485f25b1784ad21eb76708 something you want to pursue? Granted, the commit is pretty big and quite messy, but I think it's a pretty good start

target_title: Draft: shell: Port to AdwNavigationView

note.body: Somewhere in the massive commit https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gnome-software/-/merge_requests/2132/diffs?commit_id=b1408faacc7b727ef6485f25b1784ad21eb76708, the issue was resolved. Not sure how, so that's fun :upside_down:

push_data.commit_title: shell: Rewrite the entire navigation code

tracker-extract-3 excessive CPU capacity consumption issue, with gnome-software open

note.body:
Yes, I did notice that you created both issues. And I am telling you that it is unlikely that the behaviour of tracker-extract-3 is causing gnome-software to consume extra CPU, or vice-versa.

In any case, the best way for you to debug this problem is to [run sysprof on gnome-software](https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gnome-software/-/issues/2703#note_2253806), and that request would be the same regardless of whether it’s in this issue or in #2703. Hence there is no point in having both issues open, and I am closing this one. We can always split out a separate issue if your sysprof logs clearly demonstrate that there are multiple independent bugs.

You would also benefit from working out why `tracker-miner-fs-3` can’t open the `/home/macellan/.cache/tracker3/files/meta.db` database file, as [Sam highlighted here](https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/localsearch/-/issues/371#note_2250047). This is quite likely the explanation (or a significant part of it) of why tracker-extract-3 is using CPU.

target_title: Backport !2150 “gs-plugin-appstream: Fix a possible memory leak” to gnome-47
tracker-extract-3 excessive CPU capacity consumption issue, with gnome-software open

note.body:
The journalctl log is not useful. If you see a process using a lot of CPU, just grab a backtrace of it in that state, maybe multiple of them, to see what it is doing. Something like this may do it:
```
gdb --batch --ex "t a a bt" --pid=`pidof gnome-software` &>gs-bt.txt
```
alternatively:
```
for i in {1..9}; do gdb --batch --ex "t a a bt" --pid=`pidof gnome-software` &>gs-bt$i.txt; sleep 0.1; done
```

I see awful CPU usage after updating gtk4 to 4.16.0, but it can be a different thing for you.

target_title: Error message doesn’t fully fit in toast on reviews dialog

note.body:
From GNOME HIG in https://developer.gnome.org/hig/patterns/feedback/dialogs.html#error-dialogs:

### Error Dialogs

Error dialogs are another type of alert dialog. These present an error message to the user and often include just a single button to close the dialog.

Error dialogs should be avoided where possible, since they are disruptive. For simple non-critical errors, toasts can be a good alternative.

target_title: Trackpad back swipe gesture to go back doesn't work when done from the page contents

note.body:
Situation clarification for those like me who thought about reporting the same issue and encountered this ticket and the one in libadwaita: this problem remains in the current GTK4+libadwaita versions, as https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/libadwaita/-/merge_requests/962 was reverted shortly after because it was causing issues in other applications (like Loupe).

@alicem said that it cannot be fixed within the GTK4 series, and will have to wait for GTK5, because unlike GTK3, "GTK4 doesn't use event sequences for scrolling AND doesn't have explicit grabs, so the only way not to have your scrolling stolen/stuck is to just not propagate any events", and "that's what scrolled window does: libadwaita doesn't get any events".

target_title: Trackpad back swipe gesture to go back doesn't work when done from the page contents

note.body: Yes, Epiphany, WebKitGTK's web page views handle two-finger swipes to go back/forward in history without problems. I don't know if WebKitGTK bypasses the whole thing though, presumably.

target_title: Unable to launch any apps from Gnome Software
Cannot launch "Adwaita Demo"

note.body:
Thanks for the link. My above comment still stands.

Launching via `Open` button is not the problem here. We just don't want `Adwita Demo` to show up in places (shell grid, menu etc) as it's not a `"conventional app"`. But, that doesn't mean we should prevent launching it from GS. Rather than finding and executing the corresponding command in console, we achieve it via `Open`.

This is clear from the spec in https://specifications.freedesktop.org/desktop-entry-spec/latest/recognized-keys.html. I've highlighted relevant section in bold.

_NoDisplay means "this application exists, but don't display it in the menus". This can be useful to e.g. associate this application with MIME types, **so that it gets launched from a file manager (or other apps),** without having a menu entry for it (there are tons of good reasons for this, including e.g. the netscape -remote, or kfmclient openURL kind of stuff)._

note.body: If a `g_return_val_if_fail()` check fails, there is a programming error somewhere in the program and it’s only a matter of time before it hits undefined behaviour or crashes. By convention, we do not waste code on trying to recover from those situations (it would be a lot of code, and basically impossible to test everywhere), so the `GError` does not get set.

target_title: Error message doesn’t fully fit in toast on reviews dialog

note.body: I’ve retitled the issue to cover only the first topic.

target_title: Error message doesn’t fully fit in toast on reviews dialog

note.body:
> 1\. Short toast space in dialogs:

This seems like a question for the designers. Are we using `AdwToast` incorrectly, or does it need to be modified to accommodate longer messages?

> 2\. Toast message + debug / warning message in console:

It’s neither a recommended or unrecommended pattern. It’s fine either way. For messages where we think it might be useful to see them in debug logs, a `g_debug()` or `g_warning()` is appropriate in addition to a toast. For messages which we probably won’t find useful for debugging issues in future, it’s unnecessary. There is no concrete rule and I don’t think there needs to be one.

target_title: Error message doesn’t fully fit in toast on reviews dialog

note.body:
Please file things like this as two separate issues instead (or, for the second one here, just an inline question in the [thread where it was brought up](https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gnome-software/-/merge_requests/1944#note_2250314), since it’s not a complex question). If you find yourself writing an issue which has multiple subheadings for questions which aren’t dependent on each other, it should be multiple issues.

Putting multiple questions into the same issue means that it’s harder to keep track of what’s been answered/discussed and what hasn’t, and the issue stays open longer. It also makes it harder to find which issue is discussing a specific question, because the issue title (“Error reporting issues”) ends up being very generic.

note.body:
https://www.freedesktop.org/software/systemd/man/devel/org.freedesktop.sysupdate1.html#Properties

> At most one target will have a class of "host"

that one target happens to be named `host` too. I don't expect that to ever change

target_title: Add plugin gs-plugin-systemd-sysupdate

note.body:
Everything that needs to be updated along with the host system would be part of the `host` target. By  the definition of a target I explained earlier, you can't have two targets that must be updated together. What you're describing is `sysext` targets that need to be updated together with the `host` target, but that means that they cannot be distinct targets.

Such extensions could exist, but they'd either be burned into the /usr image, or the extensions would  just be another "transfer" in the host's sysupdate definitions. In other words: such extensions would be updated via a file in /usr/lib/sysupdate.d, which means they'd be part of the `host` target.

Also: even if you'd have separate targets for the extensions and the host system, there would be no way for sysupdate to enumerate sysexts that don't exist yet and offer them for you to install! sysupdate offers sysext targets by actually scanning the disk for them. If the sysext isn't installed, there's nothing to find, and thus the target wouldn't exist.

There's an additional concept for optional parts of a target, which is called "optional features". Optional features can be turned on/off, and then the following update will either download the additional content or uninstall it. The plugin should eventually support features, once support for them lands upstream.

target_title: Add plugin gs-plugin-systemd-sysupdate

> IIUC, the callback (`review_action_completed_cb()`) will be called only in the next invocation of the main loop, not in the same context of `g_cancellable_cancel()` from `gs_app_reviews_dialog_dispose()`.

Ah, I see. Correct. In that case, the widgets still don’t need to be reffed, but you should return early from `review_action_completed_cb()` if the operation failed with `G_IO_ERROR_CANCELLED`. There’s no point in reffing the widgets so they can be updated because the dialog will have been hidden by this point anyway.

target_title: The `<provides><id>foo</id></provides>` is not supported by addons

note.body:
Thanks for the additional detail. What version of gnome-software are you using?

> Documentation also suggests this could be the appropriate medicine. That is what I have tried but it does not help.

Yes, gnome-software should handle that — it’s a bug that it doesn’t, if you’re running the latest version of gnome-software, and that’s why this issue is still open to track fixing that. However, we are low on person power and fixing it is not a high priority (this is the only app I’ve ever heard of it affecting), and even if it were fixed today it would be 6–12 months until the fixed version of gnome-software reached most users. So a more immediate fix is to change the metainfo.

> Maybe the addon can even have multiple `<extends>`?

[Yes](https://www.freedesktop.org/software/appstream/docs/sect-Metadata-Addon.html#tag-extends). This is probably the easiest (and most correct) fix to make in the short term.

> Of course one option is to update all the 20+ addons in Fedora to use `<extends>org.vim.Vim</extends>` but they should likely be also updated upstream and which might break other distributions? I don't know.

The metainfo IDs used in the Fedora packages should be the ones chosen by upstream. If Fedora is changing metainfo IDs for apps/addons when packaging them, then that is a very bad idea and should be stopped. IDs are used to match apps between different sources (for example, matching the RPM from Fedora repos with the Vim flatpak from flathub) so that gnome-software can display them together rather than as duplicates in the app list.

> Or maybe the Vim `<id>` tag should be reverted. But that change happened two years ago and it was stressed multiple times that `<id>` should not be changed.

No, that’ll just cause all the ID renaming pain all over again, for no gain.

I agree it should be ideally split, but as long as there is no way to achieve it with the PackageKit it doesn't make sense to have a bug here.

target_title: The `<provides><id>foo</id></provides>` is not supported by addons

note.body:
The history in Fedora which brought me here was as follows.

1) Vim had metainfo with `<id>gvim.desktop</id>`
2) Addonds started to pop-up with `<extends>gvim.desktop</extends>`
3) Later the Vim metainfo was changed to `<id>org.vim.Vim</id>` without considering the addons (and probably lot of other stuff).
4) Adding the `<provides><id>gvim.desktop</id></provides>` into Vim metadata was suggested to me on several places to fix the situation. Documentation also suggests this could be the appropriate medicine. That is what I have tried but it does not help.

Of course one option is to update all the 20+ addons in Fedora to use `<extends>org.vim.Vim</extends>` but they should likely be also updated upstream and which might break other distributions? I don't know. Maybe the addon can even have multiple `<extends>`?

Or maybe the Vim `<id>` tag should be reverted. But that change happened two years ago and it was stressed multiple times that `<id>` should not be changed.

target_title: Add plugin gs-plugin-systemd-sysupdate

note.body:
Can an OS ship with extensions and expect some to be installed by default? I can imagine OSes have flavors and use extensions to handle them, e.g. GNOME OS and GNOME OS Mobile could have the same base but the later would have a Mobile extension that replace GNOME Shell by GNOME Shell Mobile. If systems can come with pre-installed extensions, we could also expect them to change which extensions are preinstalled over time, adding some, removing others… shouldn't installing and uninstalling extensions be part of the regular upgrade mechanism? Granted, maybe extensions shouldn't be used for that in the first place, I don't know what the intended use-cases are.

Anyway, I'll follow your recommendations, I'm just trying to better understand sysext and sysupdate. :slight_smile:

Here's a fun line of CSS you can put in the inspector that can cause terrible performance:

`flowbox > :hover:nth-child(even) ~ * { background: red; }`

(And yes, I chose that deliberately to make a point. I'm not saying gnome-software does something like it.)

target_title: Lower framerates when scrolling on home page entries vs on the sides margins

note.body:
What's happening in the sysprof logs is that CSS recomputes take too long. Unfortunately GTK doesn't have a good way to tell why that happens, which just leaves guessing. And it's possible that CSS changes do not just change the widget itself, but siblings, too - all of them if any part of the theme uses `:nth-child()`, some if it uses `:first-child`. And guessing is hard because CSS can change for all sorts of reasons:

* adding/removing widgets

* changing widgets (adding/removing style classes, either directly or via APIs that do that)

* user input (`:hover` is like adding/removing a style class)

* other less likely things I'm forgetting

All of that is cached in various ways, but if you happen to hit a slow path, you get sysprof logs like this.

target_title: The `<provides><id>foo</id></provides>` is not supported by addons

note.body:
After a lot of staring at this bug report and trying to work out what you mean, I *think* you’re saying that currently the following works in the metainfo for the addon:
```xml
<extends>org.vim.Vim</extends>
```

but you would additionally like the following to work (in the metainfo for the addon):
```xml
<extends>gvim.desktop</extends>
```

where `gvim.desktop` is defined as a `<provides>` in the main application’s metainfo:
```xml
<provides>
  <id>gvim.desktop</id>
</provides>
```

This is pretty niche. My advice would be to just update your metainfo so it uses the app’s main ID (i.e. the metainfo which currently works). There should be no need for backwards compatibility in metainfo, as all repository metainfo should be fairly up to date.

Technically gnome-software probably should support this through its support for appstream component merging (`gs_appstream_apply_merges_cb()`).

What version of gnome-software are you running?

target_title: Add plugin gs-plugin-systemd-sysupdate

note.body:
> Maybe it's worthwhile to use a different approach? Presumably these tests run during CI. Maybe it's worth running the _real_ sysupdated with bogus configuration to exercise all the codepaths in gnome-software without needing an actual distro to upgrade. This is the approach systemd takes in its own CI: drops a bunch of sysupdate configs in /run and then actually creates and applies updates.

I think that what’s here is not ideal, but is OK. The tests here need to:
 * Allow us to confidently fix bugs in the sysupdated plugin in gnome-software and catch regressions
 * Refactor higher-level parts of gnome-software and catch regressions
 * Not change actual system state
 * Not require root privileges to run
 * Execute quickly
 * Be maintainable — if the tests are hard to understand then nobody will modify or extend them, and we’ll end up with them eventually being useless or removed

The sysupdated D-Bus API is a natural interface to form the boundary of the tests, because it’s documented, stable, and we can use existing test tools to build the tests. That last point hasn’t actually happened here, and if reworking the MR was free then I would ask for it to be rewritten to use libglib-testing’s D-Bus mock code, which I think would make the tests simpler to understand. But unfortunately reworking the MR is not free, so I think this is too big a change to ask for.

Running the real sysupdated as part of the tests means we are necessarily running a subprocess, which adds a lot of complexity and potential failure to the test harness, and it ties us in to staying up to date with every change that happens to the sysupdated process context — new versions of sysupdated might start looking for additional config files, or look for new default config keys which gnome-software has not previously provided. I worry that it would tie us in to slightly more demanding maintenance. That’s not a workload that the gnome-software maintainers can handle at the moment.

Splitting the tests and test harness at the D-Bus interface gives us guarantees of backwards compatibility which sysupdated necessarily has to provide as part of publishing that interface. That helps a lot with maintenance.

It also means we don’t need to run a subprocess and then try to work out what’s gone wrong inside the subprocess when a test fails.

> But you can go a step further and run the real sysupdated with a stubbed-out sysupdate worker. That way you can test all the real dbus without actually updating anything. The one issue I can think of is that the interface between sysupdated and sysupdate is undocumented, but that might be A-OK for a test case (especially for a slow-moving distro component like systemd...)

That sounds even less maintainable, as now we’re running a sysupdated subprocess _and_ implementing an additional undocumented D-Bus API.

note.body:
version numbers do not include target names. So the `host` target is of the current version `t.0` and latest version `t.1`.

`host@t.0` is the CLI syntax for `updatectl` for picking a specific version to install. The syntax there is specified as TARGET[@VERSION]. So you can `updatectl update host@t.1` to "update the host target to the t.1 version" or call `org.freedesktop.sysupdate1.Target.Update("t.1")` on `/org/freedesktop/sysupdate1/target/host`.

Sorry I didn't look at this earlier. target_title: Add plugin gs-plugin-systemd-sysupdate

note.body:
An update of the `host` target is _not_ a distro-upgrade.

The big fancy distro upgrade banner has a lot of somewhat unwanted semantics for a `host` update. It doesn't auto-download or auto-install the update, because the user should opt into a big version bump. It has different notification patterns, with the intent to intice a user to switch to the "new latest and greatest release". The banner has space for fancy art, and a link to a big blog release explaining the new OS version. Etc. The `host` target updates will be boring security updates 9 times out of 10, and minor releases the rest of the time. So, there's no reason to _not_ auto-update and there's also no reason to pester the user about new features when there will be none. And we're not going to have big release art and fanfare about these minor updates.

The banner should be reserved for major version bumps, i.e. GNOME 47 -> GNOME 48. These version bumps are represented via update streams, which aren't landed in sysupdated upstream yet. Note that the banner (a new available update stream) and the `host` target can coexist! You could be on GNOME 47, and receive a security update, while GNOME 48 is already available. Then the banner would advertise the benefits of upgrading to GNOME 48, meanwhile the `host` target will be updated like any other target with boring fixups for GNOME 47.

This mirrors how other OSs, like iOS, do things too. You don't get a fancy banner for iOS 17.3.0 -> 17.3.1. You get a fancy banner for iOS 17.* -> 18.* though!

target_title: Add plugin gs-plugin-systemd-sysupdate

note.body:
I wouldn't say that a single update target will be typical.

At minimum, GNOME OS will have the host system, and the UEFI shim (as a component)

In corporate deployments, there will likely be a confext involved. Other sysupdate distros may want to ship the NVIDIA driver as a sysext. Etc
