note.body:
Appstream should be used for this, as mentioned above.

But, this is probably an acceptable fallback for the `host` target (and the `host` target only), in case the distributor doesn't include any appstream metadata. On the other hand, they distro really should include metadata and so maybe it's acceptable to hide even the `host` target unless it has metadata attached. I don't feel too strongly about it... GNOME OS will ship proper metadata.

If you decide to keep the fallback, I wouldn't bother caching it here. Just get the OS release metadata when trying to construct the GsApp for the `host` target. There's only ever the one `host` target, and since you cache the whole GsApp this initialization will only run exactly once.

note.body: Slightly more complicated. Yes, 0 is success and everything else is failure. But a positive number is an exit code, and a negative number is an errno code. The distinction matters, because the negative number lets you log a more meaningful error message.

target_title: Add plugin gs-plugin-systemd-sysupdate

note.body:
I'd say that, for the time being, this plugin should _only_ be about updating stuff that's already installed.

It's possible, and even likely, that you'd _install_ a sysext/confext/portable/etc differently than you'd update one. Possibly not even using sysupdate. So I would build in no support for this.

I think it's technically possible for sysext to install a component that's not actually installed yet. However, that's not an intended feature, and a component that's not installed is (IMO) a botched installation of the OS in the first place. Just claim that a target that's missing the current_version has a version of "Unknown" or something. Never advertise a target as AVAILABLE, only ever as UPDATABLE

target_title: Add plugin gs-plugin-systemd-sysupdate

note.body:
This method takes the wrong approach. The sysupdated dbus API exposes appstream metadata to the gnome-software for this very reason. The API provides URLs: you're supposed to use gnome-software's various existing helpers to fetch this metadata, and then create GsApp instances from this metadata. That's the intended solution here...

This metadata contains everything you hard-code here: a display name, a rich description of what the component is, rich release notes with formatting and markup, all localized. Also, license information, icons, etc.

target_title: Add plugin gs-plugin-systemd-sysupdate

note.body:
This is incorrect. What you're describing here is a component, which is a kind of target but is not itself the definition of a target.

The definition of a "target" is "something that can be updated independently of other targets".

Targets are split into "classes" that sysupdate enumerates at runtime and exposes via dbus:

- The host system, `host`. Those are the default definitions in `/usr/lib/sysupdate.d/`, etc
- A component, which by definition is something that's updated independently from the host system. These are named `component:$NAME`, and are enumerated from `/usr/lib/sysupdate.$NAME.d/`, etc
- Machined machines. These are enumerated in /var/lib/machines (and other search paths), and then if the machine has a sysupdate `host` target inside it'll be exposed as a `machine:$NAME` target outside. These for for nspawn containers, and possibly vmspawn VMs too?
- sysexts. These are enumerated in the /var/lib/extensions (and other search paths). It's actually not completely possible to configure this right at the moment, but it's here for completeness. In theory you could have a sysext that updates independently from the host system by putting content into /opt. In practice, sysupdate doesn't look for configs in /opt, so it doesn't work quite right. That's a bug / missing feature in sysupdate that may be fixed whenever
- confexts. These are enumerated in similar places to sysexts. These _should_ be updated independently of the host system, but again suffer from the issue where in practice there's no good place to put sysupdate config files inside of a confext. Again, missing functionality in sysupdate and will be fixed eventually.
- portable services. Again: we enumerate them in /var/lib/..., then if they have sysext configs inside we advertise to update them. This is untested, so IDK if it actually works right. It should in theory, I suppose.
- Streams. These aren't actually merged yet, and while writing out why these are targets I kinda decided that they shouldn't be. See here for more discussion: https://github.com/systemd/systemd/pull/33952

What I meant was that any such banners/dialogs/whatever (the fedora-third-party used to be a banner, which turned into a dialog semi-recently) should be done by the distro, when _they_ know it's appropriate for them. Violation and appropriateness are two different things.

The above explanation kind of deviates from the violation premises mentioned in https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gnome-software/-/issues/2685#note_2244521, which is more serious. What I understand is https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gnome-software/-/issues/2685#note_2244782 might not be a violation. If it were one, GNOME Software would have never shipped `fedora-third-party`.

> should be done by the distro, when _they_ know it's appropriate for them.

Honestly, I don't think any distro is going to do that. If we implement the feature, and provide the `enable / disable` setting as a `GSettings` key, distros will at most modify it to suite their needs.

note.body:
> I'm surprised the gnome-software was chosen to install the app, because the flatpak file handler .desktop file should be installed only when the plugin is installed. Is there a packaging bug here?

1. One could open any the package formats with any other (thru manual app selection), as all are shown as `Software Install`.

```sh
./gnome-software-local-file-fwupd.desktop.in:Name=Software Install
./gnome-software-local-file-fwupd.desktop.in:Exec=gnome-software --local-filename %f

./gnome-software-local-file-packagekit.desktop.in:Name=Software Install
./gnome-software-local-file-packagekit.desktop.in:Exec=gnome-software --local-filename %f

./gnome-software-local-file-flatpak.desktop.in:Name=Software Install
./gnome-software-local-file-flatpak.desktop.in:Exec=gnome-software --local-filename %f

./gnome-software-local-file-snap.desktop.in:Name=Software Install
./gnome-software-local-file-snap.desktop.in:Exec=gnome-software --local-filename %f
```

2. One could run `gnome-software --local-filename [flatpak/flatpak-ref]` in command line.

note.body:
Oh, I found the trick: the issue did not occur on my computers because I waited "too long" after the app startup. To make the worst symptoms of this bug happen, you must try to scroll the apps browsing view not too long after launching GNOME Software. The easiest way to reproduce it is:

1. Kill any gnome-software process
2. Launch GNOME Software
3. As soon as the icons of the currently visible home view load, click the "Work" apps category browser
4. As soon as the icons of the currently visible part of the view have loaded (ex: after 3-5 seconds or so), start trying to touchpad-scroll with the mouse hovering the items.

Here are some sysprof captures of the two situations:

* [scrolling after everything is loaded - sysprof capture](/uploads/36bdef9d658f8ffbc8d4885011e40a22/GNOME_Software_47_-_scrolling_apps_browser_after_everything_is_loaded_-_sysprof_capture.tar.xz):  
When you have waited a long time after startup before trying to scroll, i.e. the initial background processing has already happened and settled
* [scrolling shortly after startup - sysprof capture](/uploads/fa3b1a0661df96b643331afd43282588/GNOME_Software_47_-_scrolling_apps_browser_immediately_after_entering_browser_view_-_sysprof_capture.tar.xz):  
When you only wait a few seconds before scrolling.

Here are the flamegraphs of those two situations:

| Scrolling after everything is loaded | Scrolling shortly after startup |
| -- | -- |
| ![GNOME_Software_47_-_scrolling_apps_browser_after_everything_is_loaded_-_flamegraph](/uploads/825c3695589858bd1d1e22697e3aa6b4/GNOME_Software_47_-_scrolling_apps_browser_after_everything_is_loaded_-_flamegraph.png) | ![GNOME_Software_47_-_scrolling_apps_browser_immediately_after_entering_browser_view_-_flamegraph_after_5_seconds](/uploads/0e87122483190c72da1d345e895b9064/GNOME_Software_47_-_scrolling_apps_browser_immediately_after_entering_browser_view_-_flamegraph_after_5_seconds.png) |

note.body:
Prior to `gnome-app-list`, we shipped `org.gnome.Software.Curated.xml` `org.gnome.Software.Featured.xml` as part of GNOME Software package, which means they are more closely associated with GS. So when distros customize the files, it was kind of okay.

But with `gnome-app-list`, distros would be stepping into `GNOME` branding area, if they customize the files (as Philip mentioned above), which I agree.

### Appstream Priority:

Are there any idea of introducing a `priority` tag in the appstream catalog XML files. (e.g 100 for low, 500 for high as with Debian APT where packages with higher priority are always preferred). That way `gnome-app-list` can install appstream files with standard priority (say, 100). Distros can put their own list with the appstream file priority to `500` etc. That way GS will load `gnome-app-list` when it's the only app list installed and will load `gentoo-app-list` (as an example) when `gentoo-app-list` is only installed or along with `gnome-app-list`.

That way, we don't need to deal with package level conflicts. `gnome-app-list`, `gentoo-app-list`, `my-app-list` can co-exist.

note.body:
There is a big difference between _encouraging_, _have a possibility_ and _what is done_.

What I wanted to say here is that the _encouragement_ to modify the `gnome-app-list` content in this document is not a good idea. The `gnome-app-list` should be mentioned as a viable dependency, to get nice content in the gnome-software (and probably other appstream consuming apps), but that's all. It's a new weak dependency after disabling install of the internal gnome-software appstream data serving similar purpose.

That what is included in the gnome-software was not meant to be used by the distros, but the past experience shows that only few distros modify it (in fact, I'm not aware of any, but I do not know many distros, thus I do not count here). Due to this the `gnome-app-list` is a good replacement and the ditros can just use it, the same way they used the internal gnome-software appstream data files.

As Philip said, distros may ship their _modifications_ (or rather _additions_) in their own separate package. If they do, they can decide whether the `gnome-app-list` content, or the internal gnome-software appstream data, is still usable for them or whether it only mixes unneeded stuff in their distro (thus to avoid the `gnome-app-list` either completely or partially).

target_title: Updating snap shows authentication dialog

note.body:
From https://snapcraft.io/docs/managing-updates, snaps are supposed to be updated automatically without user intervention (default is 4 times in a day, as shown below).

```
$ snap refresh --time
timer: 00:00~24:00/4
last: today at 18:39 IST
next: n/a
```

This is possible since `snapd` always runs (as root) and keeps the system updated. So, the `unattended updates` use-case which is why `flatpak` [update policy doesn't use auth](https://github.com/flatpak/flatpak/blob/main/system-helper/org.freedesktop.Flatpak.policy.in#L53-L59), is taken care of by snap this way (via automatically `refresh`ing [a.k.a updating] 4 times daily). It's just when user initiates an update, the Polkit authorization is needed.

note.body:
> If `XYZ` linux distro wants to customize the curated / featured apps, what exactly should the distro maintainers do ?

Ship their own metainfo files in a separate package from `gnome-app-list`. Install that package by default, and don’t install (or don’t even package) `gnome-app-list`.

The metainfo files would be structured like the ones in `gnome-app-list`.

Encouraging them to modify the files in `gnome-app-list` makes it look like the resulting list is endorsed by GNOME (because it’s still labelled as ‘gnome app list’). That’s not desirable: it should be obvious that the resulting list is curated by the distro and not GNOME.

note.body:
Thinking on this some more, not sure this needs status page at all, since checking for updates is intermittent or in the background and separate from installing updates--you would also need some sort of notification here that Software isn't checking for updates because of a metered connection when it's doing so in the background

I would advocate for a dialog (and probably a notification) that appears when Software attempts to check for updates while on a metered connection on launch--or if the user clicks the button for a manual update check--that prompts the user what they want to do. The status page approach does not account for staged updates and how to present that downloading and installing those updates on a metered connection may also incur charges, etc.

Seems to me what is needed, if a user's connection is permanently metered, is some way for Software to be allowed to override that state and always check for updates, otherwise they will always be pestered with a dialog or status page. OR: to have an option in settings to not check or always check for updates on a metered connection that is available in Software's preferences.

Thus, from my point of view, a note of:
```
The gnome-software does not ship a list of featured nor curated apps. These are taken from the `gnome-app-list` project. To add a vendor-specific apps, one can use:

target_title: Updating snap shows authentication dialog

note.body:
No, doing so relies on gnome-software replicating how snapd does its authorisation checks — gnome-software would need to know about the polkit actions which are queried, and any arguments passed to those actions, and that implementation would need to be kept in sync with snapd’s implementation. That’s not worth the maintenance for being able to display a label to indicate that clicking a button will potentially pop up an authentication dialog.

I can’t see a reason for snapd to require authentication to install updates, for the same reason that flatpak doesn’t require authentication to install updates. You shouldn’t need an admin around just to keep your computer up to date. That’s the fix here.

target_title: Updating snap shows authentication dialog

note.body:
I think this is possible in runtime via [polkit-authority-check-authorization()](https://www.freedesktop.org/software/polkit/docs/latest/PolkitAuthority.html#polkit-authority-check-authorization) async API.

This can be quickly checked with `pkcheck` command which uses `polkit_authority_check_authorization()` internally.

Here are the command outputs before and after GNOME Software snap PolKit authorization.
 
### Before authorization:

```
$ pkcheck -p $(pgrep gnome-software) -a "io.snapcraft.snapd.manage"
polkit\56retains_authorization_after_challenge=1
Authorization requires authentication and -u wasn't passed.
```
The above result can be collected via `polkit_authorization_result_get_is_authorized()` which should return `FALSE` when not authorized, and `TRUE` otherwise.

### After successful authorization:

```
$ pkcheck -p $(pgrep gnome-software) -a "io.snapcraft.snapd.manage"
polkit\56temporary_authorization_id=tmpauthz3
```

target_title: Updating snap shows authentication dialog

note.body:
The polkit policies are from upstream `snapd`:

Source: https://github.com/canonical/snapd/blob/master/data/polkit/io.snapcraft.snapd.policy#L20-L28

```xml
  <action id="io.snapcraft.snapd.manage">
    <description gettext-domain="snappy">Install, update, or remove packages</description>
    <message gettext-domain="snappy">Authentication is required to install, update, or remove packages</message>
    <defaults>
      <allow_any>auth_admin</allow_any>
      <allow_inactive>auth_admin</allow_inactive>
      <allow_active>auth_admin_keep</allow_active>
    </defaults>
  </action>
```

target_title: "Proprietary" license is interpreted as the special license for snap

note.body:
> License of `vivaldi`:
>
> ```
> $ grep license /snap/vivaldi/current/usr/share/appdata/vivaldi.appdata.xml 
>   <metadata_license>CC0-1.0</metadata_license>
>   <project_license>LicenseRef-proprietary</project_license>
> ```

`LicenseRef-proprietary` is [correct](https://www.freedesktop.org/software/appstream/docs/chap-Metadata.html#tag-project_license).

The license tile should be showing the ‘Proprietary’ title rather than the ‘Special License’ title, so yes, something seems wrong here. (It would have been clearer if you’d stated that this difference is what you were reporting in the first post :smile: .)

> I find licenses differing from upstream package and snap. E.g for `eog` snap:

Are you suggesting that `snapd_snap_get_license()` might not be returning the license expression from the metainfo file? Given what you’ve said, that seems likely to me. You’ll have to debug it (use `gdb`) yourself though, because I’m not getting involved in snap.

Alternatively ping robert.ancell as he technically maintains the snap plugin (or knows who’s currently assigned to it at Canonical).

target_title: "Proprietary" license is interpreted as the special license for snap

note.body:
1. Appears `snapd_snap_get_license()` should be returning SPDX license expression from API docs.

   From: http://people.ubuntu.com/~robert-ancell/snapd-glib/reference/SnapdSnap.html#snapd-snap-get-license

   ```
   const gchar *
   snapd_snap_get_license (SnapdSnap *snap);

   Gets the SPDX license expression for this snap, e.g. "GPL-3.0+".
   ```

2. License of `vivaldi`:

   ```

target_title: Add plugin gs-plugin-systemd-sysupdate

note.body:
```suggestion:-3+0
	g_cancellable_disconnect (cancellable, data->cancelled_id);

```

`g_cancellable_disconnect()` is explicitly documented as being a no-op if either the cancellable is `NULL` or the ID is `0`.

**However** I think it would be safer to do the cancellable disconnection in `gs_plugin_systemd_sysupdate_update_apps_data_free()`, as that’s the owner of the struct which holds the signal connection ID. There is actually no guarantee that an async `*_finish()` function will be called; it’s more robust to free up variables from the async scope in the `GDestroyNotify` for the task data. (This is a generally applicable pattern.)

target_title: Add plugin gs-plugin-systemd-sysupdate

note.body:
```suggestion:-0+0
		if (check_to_be_removed (key, value, NULL))) {
```

Nitpick: Reusing this function means there’s no chance of the logic in this loop drifting out of sync with the `g_hash_table_foreach_remove()` logic below in future.

target_title: Add plugin gs-plugin-systemd-sysupdate

note.body:
```suggestion:-0+0
	self->last_refresh_usecs += delta_usecs;
```

Nitpick: It’s bad practice to call a clock function like `g_get_monotonic_time()` more than once in a function, as its return value could change on subsequent calls and that could mess your calculations up. In this case, it’s probably not a problem, but best to stick to best practices.

target_title: Add plugin gs-plugin-systemd-sysupdate

note.body:
Please propagate errors from `refine_app_from_json()` using a `GError` so the calling code gets to choose how to handle them.

In this case, I think the calling code will call `g_debug()` with a prefix and the error message, because we don’t want to fail the overall refine operation because a single app has failed refining. But by propagating the error there’s the scope for handling it mechanically or propagating it further if needed.

target_title: Add plugin gs-plugin-systemd-sysupdate

note.body:
Please file an issue against systemd-sysupdate requesting a proper spec for this JSON format, as the exact semantics of the different members will become hazy over time as the people who originally wrote it move on. For example, what does `protected` mean? Is it possible for both `newest` and `obsolete` to be set at the same time? Is any format imposed on `version` strings, and how are they compared to form a total order?

Ideally, the spec would also come with a [JSON Schema](https://json-schema.org/) for the format.

Merging this MR doesn’t have to block on such a spec being available, but I would like to see a `FIXME` comment here which links to the issue, so we have somewhere to look for it when trying to understand and maintain this code in future.

target_title: Add plugin gs-plugin-systemd-sysupdate

note.body:
It would be better to create the proxy *without* spawning systemd-sysupdate. gnome-software starts on user login, and the fewer things we cause to be spawned at that point, the faster login (and system startup in general) will be.

If you only need to know whether systemd-sysupdate is supported on the system, you can:
 * Create the proxy with the `G_DBUS_PROXY_FLAGS_DO_NOT_AUTO_START_AT_CONSTRUCTION` flag
 * Call [`org.freedesktop.DBus.ListActivatableNames`](https://dbus.freedesktop.org/doc/dbus-specification.html#bus-messages-list-activatable-names`) and see if systemd-sysupdate is listed there; this checks whether it’s D-Bus-activatable without actually activating it

target_title: Make review submission api async

note.body: It might not be the best design (I don’t know, I’ve only glanced at it for 5s before writing this comment), but if there’s no demonstrable need to change it then it’s not worth spending time changing and reviewing. There are much more important things to spend time on. Every time we change code we introduce the possibility for new bugs, so every change has a downside which needs to be balanced against the upside.

target_title: Make review submission api async

note.body:
I always try to be careful to make the job easier for reviewing code. In this specific case, lot of ODRS related fixes were merged, which I wanted to be part of this MR, so I don't have to deal with invalid failures (which were already fixed) while testing the changes (which would be a waste of time).

If there is a huge unrelated change like [this](https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gnome-software/-/merge_requests/1944/diffs?diff_id=1243088&start_sha=4c209c089b0b71082674c66419587f43827e4568), it's always just rebasing + fixing code conflict (and not a review candidate). I normally make it explicit via a comment, but haven't encountered a scenario so far in GNOME Software MRs.

note.body:
> would allow code to be moved from `gs-details-page.c` to `gs-review-dialog.c`.

Would that help with anything?

I don’t see a problem with the code being in `gs-details-page.c`. It means that `GsReviewDialog` doesn’t have to deal with the plugin loader or ODRS provider, or the network, and can just be a data collection form.

target_title: Make review submission api async

note.body:
Please don’t rebase a branch once it’s been proposed as a merge request. Doing so makes it hard to see the changes between versions of the MR — GitLab’s ‘compare with previous version’ gives hard-to-use results like [this](https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gnome-software/-/merge_requests/1944/diffs?diff_id=1243088&start_sha=4c209c089b0b71082674c66419587f43827e4568). That means the reviewer has to re-review all the changes from scratch.

There is no benefit to rebasing unless there are actually merge conflicts, in which case those should be resolved after review is complete and the MR is accepted. (I realise a rebase was needed here at some point for dropping libsoup 2, but that should happen once the review is complete, or if it’s specifically asked for by the reviewer.) Thanks.

target_title: Pleasure DVR has a Teen Age Rating

note.body:
I misread `as_content_rating_get_minimum_age ()` which returns the highest (and not lowest) age rating of the CSM age ratings. I've updated above comment accordingly.

Still, age rating from CSM is not convincing (I see there are disclaimers in `as_content_rating_get_minimum_age()`), and GNOME Software tones it down even further.

target_title: Pleasure DVR has a Teen Age Rating

note.body:
This comes from appstream and not GNOME Software.

FWIW, appstream uses [Common Sense Media ratings](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Common_Sense_Media) in [as-content-rating.c#L1215-L1216](https://github.com/ximion/appstream/blob/main/src/as-content-rating.c#L1215-L1216) as shown below.

```c
	{ "sex-nudity",		AS_OARS_VERSION_1_0, 0, 12, 14, 14},
	{ "sex-themes",		AS_OARS_VERSION_1_0, 0, 13, 14, 15},
```

The last 3 values are `mild`, `moderate` and `intense` age ratings for the specified category.

And `as_content_rating_get_minimum_age()` tends to get the highest values of them (14 [`sex-nudity::intense`] & 15 [`sex-themes::intense`]), which is 15 which is termed as `Teen` under ESRB rating system. Refer https://freedesktop.org/software/appstream/docs/api/method.ContentRating.get_minimum_age.html.

### Thoughts:

- I cannot find the source of where the CSM ratings data was obtained from.
- Discover interprets this situation a bit better `15+ Intense Content` makes more sense than just abstract `Teen` which could mean 13 (Thir**Teen**) as well.

/cc @mak

target_title: Pleasure DVR has a Teen Age Rating

note.body:
This is still a valid issue. The maintainer confirmed that the metadata contains the correct OARS tags, and gnome-software still shows it with a Teen age rating.

KDE Discover shows it as 15+, which also concerns me, but shows that the age rating is decided by the software manager, not the package.

When inspecting the content attributes through gnome-software, it even shows that the app contains explicit nudity and graphic sexual behavior, but it is apparently still suitable for teenagers.

![image](/uploads/ffc108c08ac30b390fb8d0bba857f384/image.png)
![image](/uploads/13c094ba8003316baeddaac11cb67e62/image.png)

target_title: Draft: Rework threading model

note.body:
A simple ping comment on the MR would be a good first step, which in most cases should elicit a response from the MR author. After a couple of unresponsive pings, the MR can be considered a candidate for closure.

In the meanwhile, some other contributor might be interested in picking up the abandoned MR (looking into the ping comments), since not all of us have the time and energy to take an MR from start to finish. For some folks, starting from a half done MR might be a good contribution candidate given the time constraint advantage of partial completed work.

target_title: Network connection incorrectly showing as metered

note.body:
On your machine, NetworkManager is guessing that the `wlo1` device *is* metered:
```
GENERAL.DEVICE:wlo1
GENERAL.METERED:yes (guessed)
```

Explicitly configure that device to not be metered and the problem should go away. You should be able to do this by ticking the ‘Metered connection’ checkbox in the network configuration, and then unticking it again.

note.body:
Interesting. So I have prepared very minimalist appstream-data which contains this .xml:
~~~xml com.hithub.wincent.command-t vim-command-t command-t Provides an extremely fast, intuitive mechanism for opening files with a minimal number of keystrokes BSD-2-Clause https://github.com/wincent/command-t org.vim.Vim.desktop org.vim.Vim.desktop vim-X11 vim GVim The VIM version of the vi editor for the X Window System Redigeer tekslêers የጽሑፍ ፋይሎች ያስተካክሉ حرّر ملفات نصية Mətn fayllarını redaktə edin Рэдагаваньне тэкставых файлаў Редактиране на текстови файлове টেক্স্ট ফাইল এডিট করুন Izmijeni tekstualne datoteke Edita fitxers de text Úprava textových souborů Golygu ffeiliau testun Rediger tekstfiler Textdateien bearbeiten Επεξεργασία αρχείων κειμένου Edit text files Edit text files Redakti tekstajn dosierojn Editar archivos de texto Redigeeri tekstifaile Editatu testu-fitxategiak ویرایش پرونده‌های متنی Muokkaa tekstitiedostoja Éditer des fichiers texte Cuir comhaid téacs in eagar લખાણ ફાઇલોમાં ફેરફાર કરો ערוך קבצי טקסט पाठ फ़ाइलें संपादित करें Uređivanje tekstualne datoteke Szövegfájlok szerkesztése Edit file teks Vinna með textaskrár Edita file di testo テキストファイルを編集します ಪಠ್ಯ ಕಡತಗಳನ್ನು ಸಂಪಾದಿಸು 텍스트 파일을 편집합니다 Redaguoti tekstines bylas Rediģēt teksta failus Уреди текстуални фајлови വാചക രചനകള് തിരുത്തുക Текст файл боловсруулах गद्य फाइल संपादित करा Edit fail teks Rediger tekstfiler पाठ फाइललाई संशोधन गर्नुहोस् Tekstbestanden bewerken Rediger tekstfiler Rediger tekstfiler ପାଠ୍ଯ ଫାଇଲଗୁଡ଼ିକୁ ସମ୍ପାଦନ କରନ୍ତୁ ਪਾਠ ਫਾਇਲਾਂ ਸੰਪਾਦਨ Edytuj pliki tekstowe Editar ficheiros de texto Edite arquivos de texto Editare fişiere text Редактирование текстовых файлов Úprava textových súborov Urejanje datotek z besedili Përpuno files teksti Уређујте текст фајлове Izmeni tekstualne datoteke Redigera textfiler உரை கோப்புகளை தொகுக்கவும் แก้ไขแฟ้มข้อความ Metin faýllary editle Metin dosyaları düzenleyin Редагувати текстові файли Soạn thảo tập tin văn bản Asspougnî des fitcs tecses 编辑文本文件 編輯文字檔

Vim is an advanced text editor that seeks to provide the power of the de-facto Unix editor 'Vi', with a more complete feature set. It's useful whether you're already using vi or using a different editor.

Vim is a highly configurable text editor built to enable efficient text editing. Vim is often called a "programmer's editor," and so useful for programming that many consider it an entire IDE. It is not just for programmers, though. Vim is perfect for all kinds of text editing, from composing email to editing configuration files.

We ship the current Vim stable release - 9.1 - with the upstream patchlevel 737 applied, which is combined into version 9.1.737 used during packaging.

 org.vim.Vim.png TextEditor Utility Text editor Editor Teksto redaktilo Texto Teksti editori muokkain Texte éditeur Téacs eagarthóir Testo エディタ テキスト текст текстовый редактор Текст едитор Metin düzenleyici редактор текст 文本 编辑器 ModernToolkit application/x-shellscript text/english text/plain text/x-c text/x-c++ text/x-c++hdr text/x-c++src text/x-chdr text/x-csrc text/x-java text/x-makefile text/x-moc text/x-pascal text/x-tcl text/x-tex Vim http://www.vim.org/ https://raw.githubusercontent.com/zdohnal/vim/zdohnal-screenshot/gvim16_9.png gvim.desktop ~~~
This is the data which are **always** used for "available" packages. For "installed" packages, the metadata from appstream-data are used as soon as the `id` matches. Everything else seems to be ignored. But without the metadata in appstream-data, I was not able to display the "addons" as part of the installed package what so ever. I think this might be a gap, although well hidden.

target_title: Draft: Rework threading model

note.body:
The following doesn't apply to this issue, but a more general view:

I understand that it would be convenient to have clean MR list, but asking contributors to close their draft MRs is not viewed as encouraging. Open draft MRs will remind the contributors that work is still pending and will encourage / push them to find time to complete it. 

Closing / Asking-To-Close draft MRs would convey a message that the MR is not important enough to stay in the queue, which discourages them in a way.

That's just my thoughts.

target_title: Review description widget is not correct

note.body: New widget as in rewriting GtkText/TextView? Not really, this is an insurmountable amount of work. I mean you can try to adapt text view, but I'd suggest just not trying to emulate an entry row - it's _never_ gonna work the same way, so doesn't seem worth the effort.

target_title: Review description widget is not correct

note.body:
Thanks for your inputs Alice!

I think the core issue here is, as part of modernizing the UI from the dialog shown in issue description of https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gnome-software/-/issues/1888, we switched to `AdwEntryRow` and that  seems to have influenced the styling of the `GtkTextView` to mimic that of `AdwEntryRow`, to offer a consistent visual appeal, which never worked.

> A multiline entry in general would make sense.

Are you suggesting a new widget here ?

target_title: Draft: Rework threading model

note.body:
`draft=no` can be useful here.

![gs-no-draft](/uploads/f3f5a4a944ff88fb4cb51664fdc55fdc/gs-no-draft.png)

target_title: Review description widget is not correct

note.body:
What you're doing right now is entirely unsupported - `GtkTextView` is `GtkScrollable` and _must_ be within a `GtkScrolledWindow` directly (or via other scrollables proxying to it). That alone would be a reason not to do it in libadwaita.

Another problem is that textview API is pretty radically different from `GtkText` (for example, it does not and cannot implement `GtkEditable`), so it's not possible to have an API even remotely resembling entry rows here.

So, this looks like a dead end, and definitely not something that should be in libadwaita. A multiline entry in general would make sense, but textview very much seems like a wrong choice.

note.body: Please, do not open merge requests for questions. Ask the questions on Discourse, as an issue or in your fork and come up with a finished thing only. All these things support links to branches. Leftover draft merge requests just clutter the queue and hide important/other changes.

target_title: Draft: Rework threading model

note.body:
There are too many `draft` merge requests here. I propose to close at least this one. The merge request queue is not the place to put something unfinished and somebody else would take care of the rest. They clutter important changes too. This one is important, but since you took over it it cannot be applied anymore and never will. Hence my proposal.

I prefer a clean backlog, rather than confusing unapplicable merge request queue. They can be always reopened.

target_title: How to test AppData

note.body:
> I'd say that the flatpak was created independently from anything else, checking the history.

This is the disadvantage of the downstream patching. The downstreams can differ. The gap between the two changes you found is several years, the rules for the ID could/did change during those years. Richard would surely pick a reverse-DNS form when it would be the suggested thing in that time.

> However, it is worth noting that the FP version has org.vim.Vim.desktop ID. Is there a chance that the .desktop suffix would be ignored for some purposes?

For this see https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gnome-software/-/issues/2663

target_title: How to test AppData

note.body:
> The ID is used also for reviews. Changing the ID means losing that.

That is very good information. I think these "details" are underdocumented a bit.

> Otherwise I cannot think of any other side effect of changing the ID, apart of the plugins, whom need to `<extend>` the new ID, not the old one. The change of the ID causes flood of changes in the related projects/packages/...

It all makes better sense now. Thx.

> In an ideal world the flatpak and the packaged apps should both have the same ID, thus they can be grouped together and the alternatives can be proposed accordingly. I do not know why flatpak changed the ID, maybe because they wanted/needed reverse-DNS form. Maybe.

I'd say that the flatpak was created independently from anything else, checking the history. [This](https://src.fedoraproject.org/rpms/vim/c/421033e3ea6dd21758bfaf424eb2592905e590a4) is the Fedora RPM and [here](https://github.com/flathub/org.vim.Vim/commit/3525afed1b0a768d7fad5eac637a003a8e8e98cb) is Flatpak.

However, it is worth noting that the FP version has `org.vim.Vim.desktop` [ID](https://github.com/flathub/org.vim.Vim/blob/914dfb153485f1a82279db33908055249d44d1ed/org.vim.Vim.appdata.xml#L8C7-L8C26). Is there a chance that the `.desktop` suffix would be ignored for some purposes?

target_title: How to test AppData

note.body:
The ID is used also for reviews. Changing the ID means losing that. Otherwise I cannot think of any other side effect of changing the ID, apart of the plugins, whom need to `<extend>` the new ID, not the old one. The change of the ID causes flood of changes in the related projects/packages/...

In an ideal world the flatpak and the packaged apps should both have the same ID, thus they can be grouped together and the alternatives can be proposed accordingly. I do not know why flatpak changed the ID, maybe because they wanted/needed reverse-DNS form. Maybe.

I cannot help with "what to do now", I'm sorry. I do not know which way would be the best. They are surely different approaches, with different consequences.

I think, if you are going to use the same app ID as the Flatpak uses, to also add to the RPM `<provides><id>old_id</id></provides>`, which, if I understand it correctly, is supposed to help to denote the ID changed. I cannot tell whether it'll pair the addons with the new ID in the gnome-software, but it should, from my point of view (if not, a bug can be filled here).

target_title: 'App Updates' / 'Requires Restart' labels in updates page is confusing

note.body:
This is a whole bikeshed I have no mental capacity to get into right now, but at least I can throw in some boundaries from my point of view:
 * gnome-software deals with more than apps (for example, codecs)
 * Users should not need to care about the difference between packaging formats when they’re applying updates — why does it matter whether an update is for a flatpak or a snap or an RPM? (They do perhaps need to care when installing the apps in the first place though)
 * Both ‘offline update’ and ‘live update’ are terrible pieces of terminology which we’re unfortunately stuck with on the PackageKit implementation side, but we absolutely should not be using these with users
  - ‘Offline update’ means the update happens on reboot. But users could easily confuse that for an update which happens when you have no network connection
  - ‘Live update’ means the update happens while the user session is running (and typically only gets applied when the user restarts whatever flatpak process has been updated), but this is quite a technical distinction and the word ‘live’ doesn’t really describe specifically what happens or what’s relevant to the user

From the user’s point of view, the only things they really need to understand from this UI are:
 - This list of apps is going to get updated
 - Some of them will require the computer to be restarted

I really don’t think we need to get into the distinction of ‘this is an app’ vs ‘this is a runtime’, because it actually doesn’t matter to the user. They all need updating.

Actually, I guess I have waded into this bikeshed, and I’m fairly convinced that the existing terminology is fine. It might not be super-precisely accurate for categorising different types of component or the process by which each one is updated, but that information is not relevant to 99.9% of people (and is actually a distraction).

I’ll close this then. If a designer thinks my reasoning is wrong and wants to propose new terminology/design for this UI then we can reassess it.

target_title: 'App Updates' / 'Requires Restart' labels in updates page is confusing
'App Updates' / 'Requires Restart' labels in updates page is confusing

note.body:
1. This concerns both offline and live update labels.

2. `App Updates` usage in not fully correct here. GNOME Software is an app manager. So, everything is an app (whether it's a Packagekit `GNOME Builder` package or the `GNOME Builder` flatpak / snap). We're using `App` to flatpak / snap. This is fine in our code, but for a user it's confusing.

3. As mentioned in issue description, we might not always have apps only as updates. In stable distros, it's mostly System updates. In flatpak / snap, it could be plain SDK + platform without any app updates. So, it's inaccurate in this aspect too.

4. If `Live Updates` doesn't feel user friendly, we can just keep `Updates`. The other label should be renamed as `Offline Updates` as mentioned above. So, this works too.

5. As an alternative to `[4]` we can also have `Flatpak Updates` / `Snap Updates` sections, instead of `App Updates` section.

target_title: How to test AppData

note.body:
By the way, when I search for `gvim` in the Software, it find one packaged only as Flatpak, one by Fedora Linux and then one on the Flathub.org. There is not shown any packaged as RPM in the gnome-software.

The dnf finds `vim-X11`, which you've installed (it's shown above). Its appstream data come from the .desktop file, thus with only a little information about the app itself (in a form of the appstream data).

When I install the package with the dnf, I can see it in the Installed tab, but when I select it, the Flatpak alternatives take over it and I've shown the Flatpak version, not the installed RPM version.

I'd say the `vim-X11` should provide its appstream data to be shown in the gnome-software (it has some rules, like good/large enough icon), and the app ID should match the one expected by the addons, or vice versa (addons to be updated).

Make the change as suggested, please.

target_title: Drop libsoup2 support

note.body:
I just created and uploaded debian v18 image with the change. I did not create a new Fedora image, because it's not needed, though I'd like you to keep the fedora.Docker file change (only make it to ask for the libsoup3-devel package instead).

A little advantage is that the debian and Fedora images will get in sync with the version.

target_title: How to test AppData

note.body:
I think I'll submit to Fedora my changes to vim-command-t extending the `<id>org.vim.Vim</id>` and see how does it look when the data propagates through the whole pipeline 🤷

I'll probably also update the vim-command-t id to rDNS notation, just to be sure.

target_title: Drop libsoup2 support

note.body: what if they change their mind and they will add a soup3 backend? Or some  other than curl, which is not soup2? Better to check for "is soup2" (whichever name it is in their case) and consider everything else as fine. After all, this is what it is all about, soup2 and soup3.

target_title: Drop libsoup2 support

note.body:
I'd not reference bug URL-s in the build error messages. You should explain the problem here, not expect anybody chasing the internet and reading lengthy bug reports.

In short, maybe something like: "Flatpak is built with libsoup2, but gnome-software uses libsoup3. These two cannot run together. Either disable build of the flatpak plugin with -Dflatpak=false or build flatpak with other than libsoup2."

target_title: Drop libsoup2 support

note.body:
`+     libsoup3-devel \`

maybe? though I guess libsoup3 is already available in both cases. Did you try it?

target_title: Drop libsoup2 support

note.body:
no such images exists (the same for Fedora). This change should not be needed, plus/minus my comment from the previous commit.

I'd probably merge the two commits, they are closely related, but I do not know what the "way-of-work" is appropriate here.

note.body:
I've made the CI changes.

Following container registry changes needed.

- Fedora image needs to remove `libsoup-devel` (as it already has `libsoup3-devel`).
- Debian image needs to remove `libsoup2.4-dev` and add `libsoup-3.0-dev`.

Refer: https://gitlab.gnome.org/sid/gnome-software/-/pipelines/741665

target_title: How to test AppData

note.body:
You can refer to the (lengthy) spec: https://www.freedesktop.org/software/appstream/docs/sect-Metadata-Application.html

but I see you already incorporated the [`<provides>` tag](https://www.freedesktop.org/software/appstream/docs/chap-Metadata.html#tag-provides) (with an `<id>` sub-element), thus you might be aware of it. It's possible these things are not properly implemented in the gnome-software, though if they "mostly work", the first impression is that the appstream data is not correct.

It would be good to check whether you are seeing the information from these new files, for example by changing summary or some such thing visible in the GUI. There use to be some caches/indexes/whatever, for the .desktop files and other for sure, I only do not recall whether also for these metainfo files.

The `<id>` in the `vim-command-t.metainfo.xml` doesn't look right, could you make it for example `com.example.vim-command-t`, if it'll change anything?

The `gnome-software --quit; gnome-software --verbose` log can show you what app you've selected in the details page, just as it prints a lot of information the app details are several lines/pages above the end of the log when the app is loaded in the details page. Search the terminal for the app ID or some such thing. It also shows there where it has got the information from.

target_title: Drop libsoup2 support

note.body: I do not plan to work on this by any means, I'm sorry.

target_title: Switch CI to libsoup3

note.body: Ouch, you are right, it's the other way around. The other one cannot be done without this one. Nonetheless, the other one has a merge request, thus let's do it within it. There is no hurry for the switch in the CI, is there?

target_title: Switch CI to libsoup3

note.body:
> This can be done only in a single shot with the libsoup2 support removal, thus I mark this as a duplicate of the other.

I think this issue can be fixed independent of #2670.

CI currently uses [-Dsoup2=true](https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gnome-software/-/blob/main/.gitlab-ci.yml#L14) as a common option for both Fedora and Debian CI. Removing `-Dsoup2=true` meson option and updating the CI with soup3 packages should use the soup3 code path in GS. After this change is merged, https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gnome-software/-/merge_requests/2139 can be rebased and merged.

Vim is a highly configurable text editor built to enable efficient text editing. Vim is often called a "programmer's editor," and so useful for programming that many consider it an entire IDE. It is not just for programmers, though. Vim is perfect for all kinds of text editing, from composing email to editing configuration files.

We ship the current Vim stable release - 9.1 - with the upstream patchlevel 737 applied, which is combined into version 9.1.737 used during packaging.

https://raw.githubusercontent.com/zdohnal/vim/zdohnal-screenshot/gvim16_9.png http://www.vim.org/ gvim.desktop ~~~
/usr/share/metainfo/vim-command-t.metainfo.xml ~~~ $ cat /usr/share/metainfo/vim-command-t.metainfo.xml vim-command-t org.vim.Vim command-t Provides an extremely fast, intuitive mechanism for opening files with a minimal number of keystrokes https://github.com/wincent/command-t CC0-1.0 BSD v.ondruch@gmail.com ~~~
Despite that, the plugins are not listed as part of "Installed" app. Is that even possible? What is puzzling me is that for some reason, the "Available" and "Installed" GVim descriptions differs. Why is that? I'd expect that I'll end up with the same information. To my understanding, the "Available" data comes from some repo information (because the description is coming from the RPM metadata), while the "Installed" are coming the `/usr/share/metainfo/gvim.appdata.xml`

note.body:
The `--show-meta-info` has some limitations, I'm not sure whether it can cope with the `Launch` button, because that requires an "installed" state on the app, which this "check what it looks like" option does not have.

If you cannot modify directly in the `/usr/.....`, try to add the file into `~/.local/share/flatpak/exports/share/metainfo/` as an ugly hack, which may or may not override the information from the `/usr/...`.

Note the similar data is also available in various consolidated appstream packs, like the files installed by `appstream-data` package in Fedora, or for flatpaks those at `~/.local/share/flatpak/appstream/flathub/x86_64/active/` and `/var/lib/flatpak/appstream/flathub/x86_64/active/`.

You can change your component to be a merge component, which will add only necessary bits to the "main" components in the appstream data. Some examples you can see [here](https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gnome-software/-/blob/main/data/assets/org.gnome.Software.Curated.xml), which add the `<kudos>` data into the apps with the given `<id>`.

We can discuss this further here, I'm closing this just because there's not much to be done on the gnome-software side with this. I can reopen if needed.

note.body:
Semantically, `GsCategoryPage:title` should be allowed to be `NULL`. The category page will not have a title to expose if it’s not got a category set on it.

It’s a layering violation to change the behaviour of `GsCategoryPage:title` to work around a limitation in one of the consumers of that property (`AdwNavigationPage:title`).

My suggestion is to use a `GBindingTransformFunc` on the binding between those two properties, which prevents `NULL` being propagated to `AdwNavigationPage:title`. Iff `GsCategoryPage:title` is `NULL`, it would set `AdwNavigationPage:title` to `""` (or `" "` if really needed) and set `AdwNavigationPage:show-title` to false.

note.body:
> Yes, G-S can't fix the data, but can handle them better

It can’t handle the data better in this situation because it can’t even tell that something’s wrong. As humans, we know what’s wrong with this data because we know what the intention was and what to expect. gnome-software can only know that by being told…and that requires being given some valid data.

> including e.g. reporting them

No, that’s the job of the packaging/validation tools. If gnome-software were to report metainfo problems, those issue reports would be duplicated for each user of gnome-software (i.e. by 5–6 orders of magnitude).

target_title: Plugins for installed app are not listed

note.body:
Yes, G-S can't fix the data, but can handle them better, including e.g. reporting them. E.g. looking at journal, there are `říj 01 14:16:11 fedora gnome-software[2817]: snapshot symbolic icon using mask` reports, which I can now relate to the wrong GVim installed icon, but it is hardly obvious what the problem really is.

Please also note that the `https://src.fedoraproject.org/rpms/vim/pull-request/25` was accepted based on the `The spec file already validates the appstream file` comment, but apparently, the validation is not enough.

IOW there are thing which could be improved to make the G-S UX better.

target_title: Package upgrade always fails if the existing package has a malformed desktop file
Updates of Flatpaks don't show changelog of new version until after update is actually performed

note.body:
This is tricky. The changelogs are from the appstream data provided by the repository, in this case Flathub. I do not know how often they update it, maybe daily? Doing an update of the whole repository content every time it changes would mean constantly downloading the new appstream data by all users, which is expensive on both server and client side. This repo appstream data is a merge of the appstream data of each app in it.

Once the app is installed, it brings in also its own "up-to-date for the installed version" appstream data, which does contain the information about the new version.

In other words, as I understand it, you'll see the future update changelogs only after the appstream data for the repo is refreshed on the server and when it is downloaded to the client. This download is done by gnome-software about once per day, if I recall correctly.

target_title: gs-os-update-page: Port update rows to AdwActionRow

note.body: Well, without an explicit label/relations, you have to use heuristics, e. g. ignoring images by default for the representation, which Orca currently does, but we don't want there. Also, by using explicit markup, you can tell the AT things like "the subtitle is less important", so it might be spoken later, for example. So, the list row is by default represented as best as it can without contextual information, but that information is sometimes needed.

target_title: Plugins for installed app are not listed

note.body:
Yes, the `<extends>` of the plugin [needs to match the `<id>` of the parent app](https://www.freedesktop.org/software/appstream/docs/sect-Metadata-Addon.html#tag-extends). This looks like a packaging issue.

One way of fixing it might be to add multiple `<extends>` keys to the plugins, matching both the old and new IDs. Another way might be to add `<provides><id>gvim.desktop</id></provides>` in the new parent app metainfo.

target_title: gs-os-update-page: Port update rows to AdwActionRow

note.body: Libadwaita does it, but update_relation actually does not an update, but a complete replacement of relations, so the libadwaita's one would be lost.

target_title: Plugins for installed app are not listed

note.body:
The app ID is `org.vim.Vim`, while the plugin extends `gvim.desktop`, and the app does not reference this in other ways too, thus they do not pair together.

It's appstream data (and the plugin) issue. If the Fedora is changing the app ID, it should update also the plugins accordingly.
